'''Harold Elwin''' "'''Bo'''" '''Bice Jr.''' (born November 1, 1975) is an American singer and musician who was the runner-up against [[Carrie Underwood]] in the [[American Idol (season 4)|fourth season]] of ''[[American Idol]]''. Prior to auditioning for ''American Idol'', Bice released a solo album as well as a few albums with his bands while performing on the night club circuit.

Bice charted in 2005 at number two on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] with a rendition of "[[Inside Your Heaven]]" from ''American Idol''. He released the album ''[[The Real Thing (Bo Bice album)|The Real Thing]]'' after ''American Idol'' to minor success before being dropped by RCA Records. He started his own record label Sugar Money and subsequently released two more albums, ''[[See the Light (Bo Bice album)|See the Light]]'' and ''[[3 (Bo Bice album)|3]].'' He was also the lead singer of [[Blood, Sweat & Tears]] from 2013 until 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bloodsweatandtears.com/ |title=Blood Sweat & Tears official web site |access-date=2014-10-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006092029/http://www.bloodsweatandtears.com/ |archive-date=2014-10-06 |url-status=live}}</ref>

== Childhood ==
Bice was born in [[Huntsville, Alabama]] to Nancy and Harold Elwin Bice. His mother was a gospel singer as were his grandmother, great-grandmother, and aunts. Bice was [[nickname]]d "Bogart" as a newborn by his grandmother, "Granny Madge", because she thought he had "[[Humphrey Bogart]] eyes". His family continued to call him Bogart, but when Bice was in kindergarten he shortened it to "Bo" because he did not think Bogart was cool. Bice's parents divorced when he was very young, and his mother remarried years later. Bice grew up with his mother and step-father, Earle Downes, a Coca-Cola manager, step-sisters Jenny and Sharan Downes, and half-brother John Cohran. Bice has two other half-siblings, Candace and Matthew, on his biological father's side. The Downes family moved around the [[Southern United States|South]] frequently. They lived in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Alabama]], and [[Florida]], including the metro area of [[Atlanta]]. In 1990 when Bice was 14 years old they moved to England, as part of his step-father's European assignment with [[Coca-Cola]] in London.

Bice spent his teenage years living in [[Gerrards Cross]]. Bice attended [[London Central High School]], a [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] school primarily for children whose parents served in the military or worked at the U.S. Embassy. In high school, he carried his [[guitar]] everywhere and played [[American football|football]]. It was around this time when Bice worked with some English [[alternative rock]] musicians.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} He formed his first band, Spinning Jenny, while living there. Bice would have graduated in 1994, but in the fall of 1993, Bice dropped out of high school just before turning 18 to move back to Alabama, where he earned his [[GED]] and attended classes at [[Calhoun Community College]] from November 1996 to May 1997.

== Career==
===Career beginnings and ''American Idol'': 1997–2005===
Upon leaving Calhoun and spending one semester at the [[University of North Alabama]] in [[Florence, Alabama|Florence]], Bice turned professional and performed in shows all across the United States, the United Kingdom, [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], and Europe. He was a veteran of the [[nightclub]] circuit, releasing his first CD in 1995 with his band Purge.<ref>{{cite web |last=Ortega |first=Shawna |url=http://www.songfacts.com/int/2008/08/bo-bice.html |title=Bo Bice: Songwriter Interviews |publisher=Songfacts |date=2008-07-23 |access-date=October 5, 2008 |archive-date=October 18, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091018125127/http://www.songfacts.com/int/2008/08/bo-bice.html |url-status=dead }}</ref> His other pre-''Idol'' bands include Blue Suede Nickel and [[Sugar Money (band)|SugarMoney]]. Among his credits were opening for [[Blackfoot (band)|Blackfoot]] and [[Warrant (American band)|Warrant]] as well as performing live and recording with [[Johnny Neel]], formerly of [[The Allman Brothers Band]]. Bice had recorded other albums prior to his stint on ''American Idol'', which included ''Ex Gratia'' (1999) with his band Purge, and ''Recipe for Flavor'' (2000) with SugarMoney. In 2001, Bice was charged with purchasing [[cocaine]] at a [[strip club]]. In 2003, Bice was arrested for possession of [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuana]], [[drug paraphernalia]] and [[public intoxication]]. He avoided jail time by agreeing to enter a [[drug rehabilitation|drug program]].<ref>[https://archive.today/20120906201505/http://www.popcrunch.com/busted-100-celebrities-arrested-for-drug-possession/Busted! 100 Celebrities Arrested For Drug Possession] from PopCrunch.com</ref><ref>[http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/0427051_bo_bice_american_idol_1.html "Idol" Finalist Dodged Cocaine, Pot Raps] from ''[[The Smoking Gun]]''</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1500954/20050428/id_0.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080502050128/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1500954/20050428/id_0.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=May 2, 2008 |title='Idol' Singer Bo Bice Has Drug Rap Sheet, Court Papers Show |publisher=MTV News}}</ref>

For the 2005 season, ''Idol'' producers raised their required age limit from 16–24 to 16–28. In August 2004, Bice’s mother and several other family members encouraged him to go try out, since he was within the eligible age limit (he would turn 29 in November 2004). Along with [[Constantine Maroulis]] and [[Taylor Hicks]] (winner of Season 5), Bice was one of the oldest contestants to audition and participate on ''American Idol''. Bice and Maroulis were among the first contestants to compete using the [[Rock music|rock]] idiom.<ref name="Kaufman">{{Cite web |last=Kaufman |first=Gil |title='American Idol' Vets Bo Bice, Constantine Maroulis Can't Stop Rockin' |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1560421/20070524/bice__bo.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070528063956/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1560421/20070524/bice__bo.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=May 28, 2007 |access-date=2016-05-17 |publisher=MTV }}</ref> His performance in the audition stage of The Allman Brothers Band's song "[[Whipping Post (song)|Whipping Post]]" drew raves from the judges. His later performances established him as one of the favorites in the competition. During the final three performance show, Bice took the risk of performing without a band or backup singers. He sang "In a Dream", an obscure song recorded by [[Badlands (American band)|Badlands]].

In June 2005, Bice was quoted in ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine that his last thought during the ''Idol'' finale was, "Please, God, don't let me win this thing."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2002&dat=20050616&id=7L8iAAAAIBAJ&sjid=E7YFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5114,4458921 |title=Bice: 'Please, God, Don't Let Me Win This Thing.' |work=Beaver County Times |date=2005-06-15 |via=Google News Archive Search}}</ref> In comments during a subsequent appearance on ''[[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]]'', Bice backed off this stance a bit, saying that he thanked all those who had voted for him. He lost the final, ending up runner-up to [[Carrie Underwood]]. In Alabama, May 24 was declared "Bo Bice Day" by Governor [[Bob Riley (Alabama)|Bob Riley]]. Two members of the group [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]] surprised Bice during his trip home from ''Idol'' and performed "[[Sweet Home Alabama]]" with him in his home town of [[Helena, Alabama]].

===Post-''Idol'', marriage and fatherhood: 2005===
Signed to [[RCA]] Records, Bice's first single, released June 21, 2005, was his version of "[[Inside Your Heaven]]". The single debuted at number two on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 Chart and number one on the ''Billboard'' Hot Single Sales chart. Bice's single replaced [[Carrie Underwood]]'s version of the same song at number one. It was [[Gold certification|certified Gold]] in late July 2005. Bice was invited to the [[Bonnaroo Music Festival]] by [[Trey Anastasio]]. He sang a song with [[Willie Nelson]] at a Birmingham concert and was invited by Nelson to perform at [[Farm Aid]]. Bice appeared on [[Carlos Santana]]'s 2005 album ''[[All That I Am (Santana album)|All That I Am]]'' with the song "Brown Skin Girl". On June 15, 2005, Bice married long-time girlfriend Caroline Fisher in [[Helena, Alabama]]. Bice had met her when he was working as a guitar store manager, and frequented the Ragtime Cafe in [[Hoover, Alabama]] where she was working her way through college as a waitress. Their first child, a son, was born in September 2005.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2005-06-30-bice-marries_x.htm |work=USA Today |title='American Idol' runner-up Bo Bice marries |date=2005-06-30}}</ref> A second son was born in August 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usmagazine.com/american-idol-bo-bice-and-wife-welcome-baby-boy |title=EXCLUSIVE: American Idol Runner-Up Bo Bice & Wife Welcome Baby Boy |date=2008-08-05 |work=Us Magazine |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080903094459/http://www.usmagazine.com/american-idol-bo-bice-and-wife-welcome-baby-boy |archive-date=2008-09-03}}</ref> A third son was born in January 2010 this was Ean Bice.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://people.com/parents/bo-bice-welcomes-son-ean-jacob/amp/ |title=Bo Bice Welcomes Son Ean Jacob |date=2010-01-22 |work=People |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100130012523/http://celebrity-babies.com/2010/01/22/bo-bice-welcomes-son-ean-jacob/ |archive-date=2010-01-30 |access-date=2020-02-25}}</ref>  Their fourth child and first daughter was born in April 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/bo-bice-baby-girl/ |title=Bo Bice Welcomes Baby Girl |date=24 April 2012 |work=Taste of Country}}</ref> They reside in [[Covington, Georgia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gocovington.com/Newsroom/newton-countys-newest-resident-bo-bice |title=Newton County's Newest Resident- Bo Bice |publisher=Covington-Newton County Chamber of Commerce |access-date=May 10, 2016 |archive-date=June 4, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604092628/http://gocovington.com/Newsroom/newton-countys-newest-resident-bo-bice |url-status=dead }}</ref>

On July 31, 2005, Bice broke his foot while performing in concert in [[Manchester, New Hampshire]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.today.com/popculture/bo-bice-busts-his-foot-onstage-wbna8790926 |title=Bo Bice busts his foot onstage |work=TODAY.com|date=August 2005 }}</ref> but carried on with the tour. On August 18, Bice, who had been suffering from stomach pain for months, was rushed to the hospital for emergency intestinal surgery to remove a blockage caused by a life-threatening intestinal condition called [[intussusception (medical disorder)|intussusception]]. He was sidelined from the tour for several shows. During his absence from the tour, fellow contestants Anwar, Nikko, Scott, Anthony and Constantine paid tribute to Bice by singing "[[Sweet Home Alabama (song)|Sweet Home Alabama]]" and wearing Bo Bice T-shirts.<ref>[http://www.foxesonidol.com/cgi-bin/ae.pl?mode=1&article=article1763.art&page=1 foxes on idol] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051016204318/http://www.foxesonidol.com/cgi-bin/ae.pl?mode=1&article=article1763.art&page=1 |date=October 16, 2005 }}</ref> Bice returned to the tour for the final two concerts in [[Syracuse, New York]], September 10 and September 11 (a [[benefit concert]] with proceeds going to the [[American Red Cross]] to help victims of [[Hurricane Katrina]]). In addition to playing that concert, he opened his home in Helena, Alabama to a family displaced by Hurricane Katrina.

On October 7, 2005, Bice introduced his own band, SugarMoney, in [[Mobile, Alabama]] at [[Bayfest (Mobile)|Bayfest]]. He performed two concerts the following week, including a benefit concert for the victims of Hurricane Katrina, but was back in the hospital the next day with surgery complications. In November Bice was named "Heartland Hero of the Week" on [[John Kasich]]'s show, ''[[Heartland with John Kasich|Heartland]]'', for giving up his house to the family displaced by Hurricane Katrina and for using his music to raise money for victims of Hurricane Katrina. [[Jim Croce]]'s family awarded Bice the "Jim Croce 20th Annual Music Award" because the Croce family had been greatly moved by Bice's performance of Croce's song "Time in a Bottle" while he was a contestant on ''American Idol''.

===''The Real Thing'' and recurring medical problems: 2005–2006===
Bice's solo debut album, ''[[The Real Thing (Bo Bice album)|The Real Thing]]'', was released on December 13, 2005. It opened at number four. ''The Real Thing'' has the seventh-highest opening for a debut album by an ''American Idol'' finalist. Bice's band at the time appears with him on three tracks on ''The Real Thing'''s DualDisc version. In January 2006, [[Country Music Television|CMT]] aired an hour-long TV special—called ''Bo Bice: In the Moment''—which chronicled Bice's life post-Idol during the recording of his album, ''The Real Thing''. Their cameras had followed Bice around for months during the making of his album. The film showed both his joy with making an album and his frustration with recording other people's pop songs. The cameras also captured the birth of his son, Aidan. On December 18, Bice started [[coughing up blood]] while rehearsing for a performance on the 2005 [[Radio Music Awards]], and had to miss the show.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/Entertainment/2005/12/19/bo_bice_out_of_radio_music_awards/7382/ |title=Top News, Latest headlines, Latest News, World News & U.S News |work=United Press International |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124151135/http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/Entertainment/2005/12/19/bo_bice_out_of_radio_music_awards/7382/ |archive-date=2009-01-24}}</ref>

In February 2006, Bice kicked off a radio promo tour. During the ensuing year of promotional appearances and touring, Bice continued to suffer with the recurring intestinal condition which had not been repaired by the August 2005 surgery. In the span of just a few months during his various tours, Bice was hospitalized 20 times, checking out of the hospitals each time to honor his performance commitments. In March 2006, Bice sang on the ''American Idol'' Top 16 Results Show. In April 2006, Bice was one of the celebrity drivers featured in the [[Toyota Pro/Celebrity Race]] held in [[Long Beach, California]], that was sponsored by [[Toyota]] to benefit various children's hospitals of Southern California. On September 12, 2006, Bice released a cover of [[The Chambers Brothers]] 1968 smash hit, "[[Time Has Come Today]]", which was the theme song for a new [[Monopoly (game)|Monopoly]] commercial. In September 2006, Bice was a special guest star in a TV special called ''Decades Rock Live: Lynyrd Skynyrd & Friends''—the friends being Bice, [[Hank Williams Jr.]], and [[3 Doors Down]].

On October 5, 2006, Bice underwent emergency surgery in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] to correct his recurring intestinal problem. The surgery came after several rounds of tests and doctors deemed his condition serious enough to operate immediately. The day after that surgery, a complication occurred and Bice had to undergo another surgery. During the subsequent recovery time, [[Ben Stiller]] invited Bice to record for the [[Will Ferrell]] film ''[[Blades of Glory]]'' produced by Stiller. Bice made several promotional appearances in connection with the releases. Bice was presented with a [[Music recording sales certification|gold record]] for ''The Real Thing'' not long after [[RCA]] dropped Bice from its roster.

=== Sugar Money Records, ''See The Light'' and ''3'': 2007–2013 ===
In the spring and summer of 2006, Bice began to talk of his hopes for a second CD, saying that "[he]'d like to go more rootsy, more country, more southern rock Bo."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.semissourian.com/story/1167395.html |title=seMissourian.com: Entertainment: Banking on Bo (09/08/06) |work=seMissourian.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061017223120/http://www.semissourian.com/story/1167395.html |archive-date=2006-10-17}}</ref> Bice encouraged his fans to start a petition asking [[Clive Davis]] for Bo's original southern rock songs on a subsequent CD. The Grassroots Coalition to Hear More Bo started the online Petition to Hear More Bo, which collected over 5,300 signatures before it was closed February 21, 2007, after word broke that Bice was no longer with RCA. Bice subsequently formed his own record label called Sugar Money/StratArt (in partnership with [[Strategic Artist Management]]). He spent the next few months planning, writing, and recording music for his new album, ''[[See the Light (Bo Bice album)|See the Light]]''. Bice introduced many of his newly written songs on a short acoustic tour which began in May 2007 and ended a few weeks later with his hospitalization for flu and bronchitis. ''[[See the Light (Bo Bice album)|See the Light]]'' was released October 23, 2007.

[[File:Bo Bice Share the Beat Atlanta 2008.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Bice in September 2008]]
In October 2007, Bice made an appearance on the TV show ''[[American Chopper|American Chopper: The Series]]'' in an episode which featured a custom-built Peavey Bike with a built-in guitar, microphone, and amp. [[Peavey Electronics|Peavey Electronics Corporation]] and Bice were working together to develop a Bo Bice guitar for their line of products. Bice had made appearances in Peavey Electronics Corporation's after school programs (in conjunction with National Afterschool Alliance) during which Peavey donated instruments to schools. In February 2008, Bice traveled to [[Kuwait]] and [[Afghanistan]] to perform for U.S. troops deployed in the region, and to thank them for their service. He went back to the war region in Fall 2008. During Spring and Summer 2008, Bice continued his tour promoting his ''See the Light'' album. He simultaneously spent a few weeks participating in a special tour called ''It Was Forty Years Ago Today'' with [[Todd Rundgren]], [[Denny Laine]], [[Lou Gramm]], and [[Christopher Cross]]. The tour paid tribute to the fortieth anniversary of the release of the [[Beatles]]' ''[[Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band|Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band]]''.

On September 13, Bice participated in "Share the Beat", a benefit for the Georgia Transplant Foundation and the James Redford Institute for Transplant Awareness. Bice sang two tracks on the ''Brothers of the Southland'' CD,<ref>[http://www.southernfriedmagazine.com/magazine/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=185&mode=thread&order=0&thold=0 Southern Fried Magazine'' August 1, 2007]</ref> a compilation spearheaded by [[The Marshall Tucker Band]]'s [[George McCorkle]] who had died from cancer just days prior to the recording sessions. On December 2, Bice was invited to Washington to perform for President Bush. Throughout 2009, Bice continued touring to support ''See the Light''. Bice did tour dates with Lynyrd Skynyrd. Bice was honored with the prestigious Lifetime Presidential Volunteer Service Award for volunteering more than 4,000 hours of his time for worthy causes, such as [[Habitat for Humanity]], Katrina assistance, [[muscular dystrophy]], organ transplants, two concert tours for the military troops in Iraq, Kuwait, and Afghanistan, Safe House, and many others. In addition to the hours for which he received recognition, he has donated instruments, music equipment, meaningful personal memorabilia, and some of his own paintings to be auctioned off for charities.

Bice started 2010 with an acoustic tour to introduce some newly written songs that he was recording for his upcoming album.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} Bice's Sugar Money record label cooperated with [[Time Life]] for the album which was called ''3'', which was officially released on [[Saguaro Road Records]] on May 18, 2010.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} On October 12, 2010, Bice guest-starred on the syndicated game show ''[[Don't Forget the Lyrics!]]'' and won the $50,000 grand prize for his charity, [[MusiCares]]. Bice was the first celebrity contestant to win the grand prize by correctly singing the lyrics to all the songs in his round.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.al.com/mcolurso/2010/10/taylor_hicks_bo_bice_on_dont_f.html |title=Bo Bice, Taylor Hicks to appear on 'Don't Forget the Lyrics' (with videos) |work=AL.com|date=October 12, 2010 }}</ref>

In 2013, Bice sang "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]" at the [[NASCAR]] [[Feed the Children 300]] in [[Sparta, Kentucky]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}}

'''Brantley Keith Gilbert'''  (born January 20, 1985) is an American [[country rock]] singer, songwriter and record producer from [[Jefferson, Georgia]]. He was originally signed to [[Colt Ford]]'s label, [[Average Joes Entertainment]], where he released ''[[Modern Day Prodigal Son]]'' and ''[[Halfway to Heaven (album)|Halfway to Heaven]]''. He is now signed to the Valory division of [[Big Machine Records]] where he has released six studio albums—a deluxe edition of ''Halfway to Heaven'', ''[[Just as I Am (Brantley Gilbert album)|Just as I Am]]'', ''[[The Devil Don't Sleep]]'', ''[[Fire & Brimstone (album)|Fire & Brimstone]]'', ''[[So Help Me God (Brantley Gilbert album)|So Help Me God]]'', [[Tattoos (Brantley Gilbert album)|''Tattoos'']], and 14 country chart entries, four of which have gone to number one. He also co-wrote (with Colt Ford) and originally recorded [[Jason Aldean]]'s singles "[[My Kinda Party (song)|My Kinda Party]]" and "[[Dirt Road Anthem]]".

==Career==
===2007–2013: ''A Modern Day Prodigal Son'' and ''Halfway to Heaven''===
Brantley Gilbert went to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] as a songwriter, where he signed to Warner Chappell Publishing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/brantley-gilbert/biography/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130109061701/http://www.cmt.com/artists/brantley-gilbert/biography/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 9, 2013 |title=Brantley Gilbert Bio |publisher=CMT |access-date=2014-07-27}}</ref> He continued performing at local venues. In 2009, he released his debut album, ''[[A Modern Day Prodigal Son]]'', under independent label [[Average Joes Entertainment]]. He followed with ''[[Halfway to Heaven (album)|Halfway to Heaven]]'' in 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.brantleygilbert.com/discography.html |title=Albums and Songs |publisher=Brantley Gilbert |access-date=2014-07-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160601073334/http://brantleygilbert.com/discography.html |archive-date=2016-06-01 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

In 2011, he signed with Valory Music Co., a division of [[Big Machine Records]], who released a deluxe edition of ''Halfway to Heaven''. The album was produced by [[Dann Huff]]. Its first two singles, "[[Country Must Be Country Wide]]" and "[[You Don't Know Her Like I Do]]", both went to number one on the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart. After them, "[[Kick It in the Sticks]]" peaked at number 34, and "[[More Than Miles]]" at number 7 on [[Country Airplay]]. He won the [[Academy of Country Music|ACM]] New Male Artist award in 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.countryweekly.com/news/2013-acm-awards-nominees-winners |title=2013 ACM Awards: Nominees & Winners |publisher=Country Weekly |date=2013-04-07 |access-date=2014-07-27 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150606020825/http://www.countryweekly.com/news/2013-acm-awards-nominees-winners |archive-date=2015-06-06 }}</ref>

===2014–2017: ''Just as I Am'' and ''The Devil Don't Sleep''===
Gilbert's second Valory album (third overall), ''[[Just as I Am (Brantley Gilbert album)|Just as I Am]]'', was released in May 2014. Its lead single, "[[Bottoms Up (Brantley Gilbert song)|Bottoms Up]]", also reached number one. The second single, "[[Small Town Throwdown]]", featured guest vocals from labelmates [[Thomas Rhett]] and [[Justin Moore]]. The third single, "[[One Hell of an Amen]]", became Brantley's fourth number one hit in 2015. The album's fourth single was "[[Stone Cold Sober (Brantley Gilbert song)|Stone Cold Sober]]", released with the album's platinum edition.

Ahead of his fourth album, ''The Devil Don't Sleep'', Gilbert released the single "[[The Weekend (Brantley Gilbert song)|The Weekend]]" as the album's lead single. Also included on the album is "[[The Ones That Like Me]]".<ref name="boot">{{cite web |url=http://theboot.com/brantley-gilbert-single-the-weekend/ |title=Brantley Gilbert Reveals New Single, 'The Weekend' [Listen]|first= Christina|last= Vinson |date=July 22, 2016|work=The Boot }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/brantley-gilbert-the-ones-that-like-me/|title=Brantley Gilert Shares New Single, 'The Ones That Like Me' [Listen]|last=Stecker|first=Liv|work=The Boot|access-date=March 14, 2018}}</ref>

A deluxe edition of ''The Devil Don't Sleep'' includes ten bonus tracks: five demos, and five tracks cut from a live performance at the [[Red Rocks Amphitheatre]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Brantley Gilbert - The Devil Don't Sleep [2 CD][Deluxe Edition] - Amazon.com Music|url=https://www.amazon.com/Devil-Dont-Sleep-CD-Deluxe/dp/B01MTX8WZW|website=Amazon.com|publisher=Amazon|accessdate=13 June 2021}}</ref>

===2018–2023: ''Fire & Brimstone'' and ''So Help Me God'' ===
In December 2018, Gilbert released a duet with [[Lindsay Ell]], "[[What Happens in a Small Town]]", as the lead single from his fifth studio album, ''[[Fire & Brimstone (album)|Fire & Brimstone]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://popculture.com/country-music/2018/12/17/brantley-gilbert-what-happens-in-a-small-town-with-lindsay-ell/|title=Brantley Gilbert Releases 'What Happens In A Small Town' With Lindsay Ell|last=Thompson|first=Gayle|work=Pop Culture|date=December 17, 2018|access-date=April 13, 2018}}</ref> The album was released in October 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://big955chicago.iheart.com/featured/brooke-taylor/content/2019-03-05-brantley-gilbert-reveals-new-album-details/|title=Brantley Gilbert Reveals New Album Details!|last=Taylor|first=Brooke|work=iHeart Radio|date=March 5, 2019|access-date=June 10, 2019}}</ref> "Fire't Up" was released as the second single off the album.<ref name="Fire’t Up">{{cite web|first=Angela|last=Stefano|title= Brantley Gilbert Is Ready to 'Fire't Up' in New Single [Listen]|url=https://theboot.com/brantley-gilbert-firet-up/|date=18 November 2019|work=The Boot}}</ref>

In June 2020, Gilbert released the single "[[Hard Days]]".<ref>{{cite web|first=Angela|last=Stefano|title= Brantley Gilbert's 'Hard Days' 'Is About Hope and Healing' [Listen]|url= https://tasteofcountry.com/brantley-gilbert-hard-days/|date=5 June 2020|work=Taste of Country}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://countryaircheck.com/pdfs/current06012020.pdf|title=Country Aircheck Weekly - June 1, 2020|work=Country Aircheck}}</ref> The song was later included on a deluxe edition of ''Fire & Brimstone''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.country965.com/2020/09/29/brantley-gilbert-to-release-deluxe-version-fire-brimstone/|title= Brantley Gilbert to Release Deluxe Version "Fire & Brimstone"|date=September 29, 2020|work=Wild Country 96.5}}</ref>

In June 2021, Gilbert released the single "[[The Worst Country Song of All Time]]", featuring [[Hardy (singer)|Hardy]] and [[Toby Keith]],<ref>{{cite web|first=Chris|last=Parton|title=Brantley Gilbert, Toby Keith and Hardy Team for 'The Worst Country Song'|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/music/brantley-gilbert-toby-keith-hardy-worst-country-song/|date=18 June 2021|work=Sounds Like Nashville}}</ref> and followed it up with the promotional single "[[Gone But Not Forgotten (song)|Gone But Not Forgotten]]" in September 2021.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wjvl.com/2021/09/17/new-at-noon-brantley-gilbert-gone-but-not-forgotten/|title=New at Noon – Brantley Gilbert "Gone But Not Forgotten"|first=Chet|last=Daniels|work=WJVL|date=September 17, 2021}}</ref> The second promotional single, "[[How to Talk to Girls (song)|How to Talk to Girls]]", was released on November 19, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web |title=When did Brantley Gilbert release “How To Talk To Girls”? |url=https://genius.com/Brantley-gilbert-how-to-talk-to-girls-lyrics/q/release-date |access-date=2024-08-28 |website=Genius}}</ref> In March 2022, Gilbert and [[Jason Aldean]] released the third promotional single, "[[Rolex on a Redneck]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/brantley-gilbert-jason-aldean-rolex-on-a-redneck/|title= Brantley Gilbert and Jason Aldean Celebrate the Rewards of Hard Work in 'Rolex on a Redneck'|work=Taste of Country|date=March 25, 2022|access-date=April 1, 2022}}</ref> In June 2022, Gilbert and [[Jelly Roll (singer)|Jelly Roll]] released the fourth promotional single, "[[Son of the Dirty South]]", which charted on multiple ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' charts.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Vaughn |first=Grace Lenehan VaughnGrace Lenehan |date=2022-06-24 |title=Listen: Brantley Gilbert and Jelly Roll Release Hard-Rocking 'Son of the Dirty South' |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/brantley-gilbert-jelly-roll-son-of-the-dirty-south/ |access-date=2024-08-29 |website=Taste of Country |language=en}}</ref>

Gilbert released his sixth studio album ''[[So Help Me God (Brantley Gilbert album)|So Help Me God]]'' on November 10, 2022 and released "[[Heaven by Then]]", featuring Blake Shelton and Vince Gill, as the album's second single.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theboot.com/brantley-gilbert-blake-shelton-vince-gill-heaven-by-then/|title=Brantley Gilbert, Blake Shelton and Vince Gill Sing 'Heaven by Then,' a Collaboration No One Saw Coming [Listen]|first=Billy|last=Dukes|work=The Boot|date=November 10, 2021}}</ref> He opened for [[Five Finger Death Punch]] on their late 2022 headlining tour along with [[Cory Marks]] in the United States.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/pro/cory-marks-major-tour-pandemic-delayed-live-music/|title=Cory Marks Ready to Support a Major Tour, After 3-Year Pandemic Delay|date=November 4, 2022|access-date=November 18, 2022|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|first=Dave|last=Brooks|url-access=subscription}}</ref> He released a deluxe edition of ''So Help Me God'' on April 21, 2023, containing five new tracks, including the promotional single "Bury Me Upside Down".<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hollabaugh |first=Lorie |date=2023-02-27 |title=Brantley Gilbert Slates Deluxe Edition Of 'So Help Me God' For April |url=https://musicrow.com/2023/02/brantley-gilbert-slates-deluxe-edition-of-so-help-me-god-for-april/ |access-date=2024-08-28 |website=MusicRow.com |language=en-US}}</ref> Gilbert joined [[Nickelback]]'s "Get Rollin' Tour" in summer 2023 in North America as an opening act alongside fellow country artist [[Josh Ross]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/nickelback-announce-summer-2023-north-154326166.html|title=Nickelback Announce Summer 2023 North American Tour|date=January 23, 2023|work=[[Yahoo! Entertainment]]|first=Spencer|last=Kaufman}}</ref>

=== 2024–present: ''Tattoos'' ===
On March 8, 2024, Gilbert released "Off The Rails", as the lead promotional single from his seventh studio album.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Iahn |first=Buddy |date=2024-03-08 |title=Brantley Gilbert delivers 'Off the Rails' |url=https://themusicuniverse.com/brantley-gilbert-delivers-off-rails/ |access-date=2024-08-22 |website=The Music Universe |language=en}}</ref> The album's first official single "Over When We're Sober", featuring [[Ashley Cooke]], was released on June 20, 2024.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-06-21 |title=Brantley Gilbert's New Single Arrives: "Over When We're Sober" Featuring Ashley Cooke |url=https://www.bigmachinelabelgroup.com/brantley-gilberts-new-single-arrives-over-when-were-sober-featuring-ashley-cooke/ |access-date=2024-08-22 |website=Big Machine Label Group |language=en-US}}</ref> 

In July 2024, Gilbert announced his seventh studio album ''[[Tattoos (Brantley Gilbert album)|Tattoos]],'' which was released on September 13, 2024.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hollabaugh |first=Lorie |date=2024-07-17 |title=Brantley Gilbert Marks Life's Ups And Downs With New Album 'Tattoos' |url=https://musicrow.com/2024/07/brantley-gilbert-marks-lifes-ups-and-downs-with-new-album-tattoos/ |access-date=2024-08-22 |website=MusicRow.com |language=en-US}}</ref> He released the songs "Me and My House", featuring [[Struggle Jennings]] and Demun Jones, and "Dirty Money", featuring [[Justin Moore]], as the album's third and fourth promotional singles, respectively.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Brenning |first=Casey |date=2024-07-17 |title=Brantley Gilbert Reveals Tattoos 9/13 + "Me And My House" ft. Struggle Jennings and Demun Jones Available Now • Red Light Management |url=https://www.redlightmanagement.com/brantley-gilbert-reveals-tattoos-9-13-me-and-my-house-ft-struggle-jennings-and-demun-jones-available-now/ |access-date=2024-08-22 |website=Red Light Management}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Iahn |first=Buddy |date=2024-08-16 |title=Brantley Gilbert releases 'Dirty Money' with Justin Moore |url=https://themusicuniverse.com/brantley-gilbert-releases-dirty-money-with-justin-moore/ |access-date=2024-08-22 |website=The Music Universe |language=en}}</ref>

==Songwriting==
In addition to his original work, Gilbert has written songs that [[Colt Ford]] and [[Jason Aldean]] have recorded. The songs "[[Dirt Road Anthem]]" (co-written and originally recorded by him and Colt Ford) and "[[My Kinda Party (song)|My Kinda Party]]" were released on Aldean's 2010 album ''[[My Kinda Party]]''. "My Kinda Party" was originally recorded by Gilbert on ''Modern Day Prodigal Son'', while "Dirt Road Anthem" was on ''Halfway to Heaven''. Aldean has also covered Gilbert's "The Best of Me", available on the iTunes release of his 2009 album ''[[Wide Open (Jason Aldean album)|Wide Open]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://todayscountrymusicvideos.com/2010/08/25/brantly-gilbert-jason-aldean/ |title=Is Brantley Gilbert Jason Aldean's Favorite Songwriter? |publisher=Today's Country Music Videos |date=2010-08-25 |access-date=2011-07-17 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110831064628/http://todayscountrymusicvideos.com/2010/08/25/brantly-gilbert-jason-aldean/ |archive-date=2011-08-31 }}</ref> Gilbert has also co-written the tracks "The Same Way" on Aldean's album ''[[9 (Jason Aldean album)|9]]''<ref>{{cite web|url= https://theboot.com/jason-aldean-album-9-information-details/ |first=Bobby|last=Moore|title= Everything We Know About Jason Aldean's New Album, '9'|work=The Boot|date=18 November 2019}}</ref> and "Small Town Small" on his album ''[[Macon, Georgia (album)|Macon, Georgia]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/song/small-town-small-mt0059771107|title=Jason Aldean - Small Town Small|website=AllMusic|accessdate=December 7, 2021}}</ref>

==Personal life==
It was announced in September 2012 that Brantley Gilbert was dating country music singer and actress [[Jana Kramer]]. They met at the CMT Music Awards in June 2012. They were engaged on January 20, 2013, his 28th birthday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/brantley-gilbert-jana-kramer-dating/|title=Brantley Gilbert Confirms That He and Jana Kramer Are Dating|last=Dukes|first=Billy|date=September 21, 2012|work=Taste of Country|access-date=September 23, 2012}}</ref> They split in August 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Takeda |first=Allison |url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/jana-kramer-fiance-brantley-gilbert-split-2013158 |title=Jana Kramer Split: Singer, Fiance Brantley Gilbert Call Off Engagement |work=Us Weekly |date=August 15, 2013 |access-date=December 18, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://thenew1037.cbslocal.com/2014/11/07/brantley-gilbert-reveals-who-hes-engaged-to/ |title=Brantley Gilbert Reveals Who He's Engaged to « the New 103.7 – Charlotte's Home for Country's Hottest Hits |access-date=2014-11-10 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.today/20141110044256/http://thenew1037.cbslocal.com/2014/11/07/brantley-gilbert-reveals-who-hes-engaged-to/ |archive-date=2014-11-10 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/article/brantley-gilbert-engaged |title=Brantley Gilbert Is Engaged! |publisher=People Magazine |date=October 21, 2014 |access-date=October 22, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023141037/http://www.people.com/article/brantley-gilbert-engaged |archive-date=October 23, 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

In 2013, Gilbert embarked on an eight-day USO tour to entertain American service members stationed in Italy and Kuwait.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uso.org/stories/1779-singer-brantley-gilbert-makes-lifelong-friends-on-his-first-uso-tour|title=Singer Brantley Gilbert Makes Lifelong Friends on His First USO Tour|last=Lee|first=Joseph Andrew|date=June 17, 2013 |publisher=United Service Organizations |access-date=October 26, 2016}}</ref>

Brantley Gilbert was in a near-fatal truck accident when he was 19.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://1023blakefm.com/near-fatal-truck-crash-leads-brantley-gilbert-to-music-2/ |title=Near-Fatal Truck Crash Leads Brantley Gilbert To Music |publisher=1023blakefm.com |access-date=2015-05-19}}</ref> Gilbert is an active Christian, and his song "My Faith In You", from his album ''Just as I Am'', speaks of his faith. In May 2015, Gilbert got a tattoo showing his support of the [[Second Amendment to the United States Constitution]].<ref name=tattoo>{{cite news |last1=Dukes |first1=Billy |title=Brantley Gilbert shows off Second Amendment tattoo |url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2015/05/06/brantley-gilbert-shows-support-second-amendment-with-new-tattoo/ |publisher=[[Fox News]] |access-date=7 May 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150507064856/https://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2015/05/06/brantley-gilbert-shows-support-second-amendment-with-new-tattoo/ |archive-date=May 7, 2015}}</ref>

Gilbert headlined the NRA's Country Concert in February 2023.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=NRA|number=1624844764326551559|title=Last night, thousands of patriotic Americans filled an arena at the Great American Outdoor Show for a SOLD-OUT NRA Country concert presented by @Magpul featuring @BrantleyGilbert with special guests @JacobBryant1 & @NateHosie! #GAOS2023}}</ref>

In April 2023, Gilbert smashed a can of [[Bud Light]] on stage after saying "Yeah, fuck that". Bud Light had recently become the focus of a [[2023 Anheuser-Busch boycott|boycott]] from conservatives because of a sponsored Instagram post by transgender activist [[Dylan Mulvaney]]."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Mordowanec |first=Nick |date=2023-04-17 |title=Country singer destroys Bud Light can after it's thrown on stage |url=https://www.newsweek.com/country-singer-destroys-bud-light-can-thrown-stage-1794842 |access-date=2023-04-19 |website=Newsweek |language=en}}</ref>{{better source needed|reason=[[WP:NEWSWEEK]]|date=April 2023}}

'''Brent Cobb''' (born August 1, 1986) is an American [[Country (music)|country music]] singer-songwriter and artist.<ref name="Scene">{{cite news | last=Freeman| first=Jon| title =Brent Cobb Paints the Joy and Sadness of Rural Life in Stunning Detail on His New LP Shine On Rainy Day| work = [[Nashville Scene]]| date =October 6, 2016 | url =http://www.nashvillescene.com/music/features/article/20835969/brent-cobb-paints-the-joy-and-sadness-of-rural-life-in-stunning-detail-on-his-new-lp-shine-on-rainy-day| accessdate =October 31, 2016}}</ref><ref name="CMT">{{cite news | last=Tingle| first=Lauren| title =Brent Cobb on the Spirit Behind Shine On Rainy Day| publisher = [[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT]]| date =October 11, 2016 | url =http://www.cmt.com/news/1771920/brent-cobb-on-the-spirit-behind-shine-on-rainy-day/| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20161012150559/http://www.cmt.com/news/1771920/brent-cobb-on-the-spirit-behind-shine-on-rainy-day/| url-status =dead| archive-date =October 12, 2016| accessdate =October 31, 2016}}</ref> Cobb has released six studio albums and one EP.<ref name="BB">{{cite news | last=Leight| first=Elias| title =Brent Cobb Steps Back Into the Spotlight With 'Shine on Rainy Day'| work = [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]| date =October 7, 2016 | url =http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/7534046/brent-cobb-shine-on-rainy-day-interview| accessdate =October 31, 2016}}</ref> His most recent album, ''Southern Star'', was released on September 22, 2023. ''Providence Canyon'' was his second major-label LP with [[Low Country Sound]], an imprint of [[Elektra Records|Elektra]].<ref name="Songwriter">{{cite news | last=Horowitz| first=Hal| title =Brent Cobb: Shine On Rainy Day| work = [[American Songwriter]]| date =October 7, 2016 | url =http://americansongwriter.com/2016/10/brent-cobb-shine-rainy-day/| accessdate =October 31, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Boot">{{cite news | last=Carr| first=Courtney| title =Brent Cobb Releases Major-Label Debut Album| work = [[The Boot (website)|The Boot]]| date =October 7, 2016 | url =http://theboot.com/brent-cobb-shine-on-rainy-day/| accessdate =October 31, 2016}}</ref> His previous album ''Shine On Rainy Day'' peaked at number 17 on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''{{'}}s [[Top Country Albums]] chart.<ref name="BBCountry">{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/brent-cobb/chart-history/clp/ |title=Brent Cobb – Chart History – Top Country Albums|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=October 31, 2016}}</ref> Cobb also received a 2018 [[Grammy Award]] nomination for this album.<ref name="grammy1">{{cite web|last=Hertweck |first=Nate |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/news/2018-grammy-nominations-best-americana-album-roundup |title=2018 GRAMMY Nominations: Best Americana Album Roundup |publisher=National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences |date=January 16, 2018 |accessdate=April 5, 2018}}</ref> Cobb has written songs for a variety of country artists, including [[Luke Bryan]], [[Kellie Pickler]], [[Kenny Chesney]], [[Miranda Lambert]], [[Little Big Town]], [[The Oak Ridge Boys]] as well as many others.<ref name="CMT"/>

==Early life==

Cobb was born in [[Americus, Georgia]]<ref name="Hour">{{cite news | last=Evans| first=Brad| title =A chat with singer/songwriter Brent Cobb – Playing Macon Aug. 26| newspaper =[[The 11th Hour (newspaper)|The 11th Hour]]| date =August 24, 2016 | url =http://11thhouronline.com/2016/08/24/a-chat-with-singersongwriter-brent-cobb/| accessdate =October 31, 2016}}</ref> but raised in the nearby town of [[Ellaville, Georgia|Ellaville]].<ref name="Scene"/><ref name="CMT"/> His father, Patrick Cobb, was an appliance repairman who was also in a rock band. Brent made his vocal debut at age 7 when he sang [[Tim McGraw]]'s "[[Don't Take the Girl]]" with his father's band in a [[Richland, Georgia]] festival performance.

As a teenager, Cobb fronted a local band called Mile Marker 5 which had some regional success and opened for larger stars.<ref name="CS">{{cite news | last=DeYoung| first=Bill| title =5 questions: Brent Cobb | newspaper =Connect Savannah| date =January 8, 2013 | url =http://www.connectsavannah.com/savannah/5-questions-brent-cobb/Content?oid=2175613| accessdate =October 31, 2016}}</ref> At age 16, Cobb met his cousin, [[Dave Cobb]], at a family funeral. Dave was a producer based in Los Angeles, and Brent gave him a demo CD. Dave, along with [[Shooter Jennings]], would later fly Brent to Los Angeles to record his debut album, ''No Place Left to Leave''.<ref name="Scene"/><ref name="BB"/><ref name="Hour"/><ref name="Tenn">{{cite news | last=Melchior| first=Tom| title =How Brent Cobb made it to Nashville| newspaper =[[The Tennessean]]| date =October 28, 2016 | url =http://www.tennessean.com/story/life/entertainment/12th/2016/10/27/how-brent-cobb-made-nashville/92839550/| accessdate =October 31, 2016}}</ref>

==Career==

Cobb recorded his debut album, ''No Place Left to Leave'', in 2006 with his cousin while in Los Angeles. However, after some time in this period, he decided to return to Georgia.

Country star and acquaintance [[Luke Bryan]] suggested Cobb move to [[Nashville]] which, in turn, he eventually did in 2008. Initially, Cobb worked as a photo developer at [[Walgreens]] but eventually managed to negotiate a songwriting contract with Carnival Music Publishing within the year.<ref name="BB"/>

After obtaining his songwriting contract, Cobb then went on to write a variety of songs for many prominent stars, such as Luke Bryan's "Tailgate Blues", [[David Nail]] and [[Frankie Ballard]]'s "Grandpa's Farm", Kellie Pickler's "Rockaway", Kenny Chesney's "Don't It", Miranda Lambert's "Old Sh!t", as well as numerous other performers.<ref name="CMT"/><ref name="Boot"/><ref name="SMN">{{cite news | last=Sickler| first=Linda| title =Georgia songwriter Brent Cobb goes from Willie Nelson to stage of his own| newspaper =[[Savannah Morning News]]| date =January 10, 2013 | url =http://savannahnow.com/do/2013-01-10/georgia-songwriter-brent-cobb-goes-willie-nelson-stage-his-own| accessdate =October 31, 2016}}</ref>

[[File:Brent Cobb Performance Third & Lindsley.jpeg|thumb|upright=0.90|Brent Cobb playing the Americana Festival at 3rd & Lindsley.]]
Cobb released a self-titled EP in 2012, and began opening for established stars such as [[Blake Shelton]] and [[Sara Evans]], playing around 120 dates per year.<ref name="BB"/><ref name="CT">{{cite news | title =Brent Cobb plays free July 6 show at Western Carolina| newspaper =[[Asheville Citizen-Times]]| date =June 28, 2016 | url =http://www.citizen-times.com/story/life/2016/06/28/brent-cobb-plays-free-july-6-show-western-carolina/86487284/| accessdate =October 31, 2016}}</ref> In 2016, his song "Down Home" appeared on [[Dave Cobb]]'s compilation album, ''Southern Family'', alongside songs from artists like Miranda Lambert, [[Chris Stapleton]], and [[Zac Brown]].<ref name="Boot"/><ref name="CT"/>

On October 7, 2016, Cobb's major-label debut album, ''Shine On Rainy Day'', was released via the Elektra Records imprint, Low Country Sound.<ref name="CMT"/><ref name="Songwriter"/><ref name="NPR">{{cite news | last=Powers| first=Ann| title =Nashville Sessions: Brent Cobb| publisher =[[NPR]]| date =June 27, 2016 | url =https://www.npr.org/sections/world-cafe/2016/06/27/483730677/nashville-sessions-brent-cobb| accessdate =October 31, 2016}}</ref> The album peaked at number 17 on ''Billboard''{{'s}} Top Country Albums chart<ref name="BBCountry"/> and at number 5 on the [[Top Heatseekers]] chart.<ref name="BBHeat">{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/brent-cobb/chart-history/tln/ |title=Brent Cobb – Chart History – Heatseekers Albums|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=October 31, 2016}}</ref> Cobb also has received a 2018 Grammy Award nomination as Best [[Americana (music)|Americana]] Album for his work on ''Shine On Rainy Day''.<ref name="grammy1"/>

Throughout 2018, Cobb went on a headline tour in support of his Low Country Sound LP album called ''Providence Canyon'', which was released May 11, 2018. Currently in 2023, Cobb was on a headline tour in support of his Ole Buddy Records LP album called ''Southern Star'', which was released September 22, 2023. 

Cobb has toured extensively as a main supporting act and special guest for Chris Stapleton on his [[Chris Stapleton's All-American Road Show Tour|All-American Road Show Tour]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Gage |first=Jeff |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/hear-brent-cobb-honor-late-musician-wayne-mills-in-new-song-w517691 |title=Hear Brent Cobb Honor Late Musician Wayne Mills in New Song |work=Rolling Stone |date=March 9, 2018 |accessdate=April 5, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chrisstapleton.com/tour/ |title=Shows |publisher=Chris Stapleton |accessdate=April 5, 2018}}</ref>
Cobb has also toured as a special guest in 2023 on [[Luke Combs]] World Tour.<ref>{{cite web|last=McArdle |first=Tommy |url=https://people.com/country/luke-combs-announces-2023-world-tour-with-riley-green-lainey-wilson-cody-johnson/ |title=Luke Combs Announces 2023 World Tour with Opening Acts Lainey Wilson, Riley Green and Cody Johnson |work=People |date=September 8, 2022 |accessdate=October 19, 2023}}</ref>

==Musical style==

Cobb's musical style has been described as "blue collar country"<ref name="CMT"/> with "[[Bluegrass (music)|bluegrass]]-leaning inclinations."<ref name="RS">{{cite news | last=Moss| first=Marissa R.| title =See Brent Cobb Record Folksy 'Down Home' With Producer Cousin Dave Cobb| work =[[Rolling Stone]]| date =March 23, 2016 | url =https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/see-brent-cobb-record-folksy-down-home-with-producer-cousin-dave-cobb-20160323| accessdate =October 31, 2016}}</ref> Some have noted that his sound is closer to Americana than contemporary country music. Jon Freeman of the ''[[Nashville Scene]]'' described Cobb's voice as "soft and sweet, with surefooted hints of soul."<ref name="Scene"/> His voice has been compared to [[Willie Nelson]], [[Al Green]],<ref name="CMT"/> and [[Merle Haggard]].<ref name="CS"/> Dave Cobb, who produced ''Shine On Rainy Day'', described the album as "pure rural, country, soul-filled music."<ref name="Boot"/>

Lyrically, Cobb's songs often detail experiences of rural living in a conversational tone<ref name="Scene"/> and "the influence of his Southern raising is weaved through nearly every note and line."<ref name="WOC">{{cite news | last=Liebig| first=Lorie| title =Brent Cobb's 'Shine On Rainy Day' is the Best Debut Album We've Heard in a Long Time| work =Wide Open Country| date =October 6, 2016 | url =http://www.wideopencountry.com/brent-cobb-shine-on-rainy-day/| accessdate =October 31, 2016}}</ref> Writing for ''Billboard'', Elias Leight noted that Cobb is "a laid back narrator, easygoing even when forlorn."<ref name="BB"/>
