'''Forrest Richard Betts''' (December 12, 1943 – April 18, 2024) was an American guitarist, singer, songwriter, composer and founding member of [[the Allman Brothers Band]]. He initially shared the band's signature dual [[lead guitar]] roles with band founder [[Duane Allman]], and assumed the solo lead after Allman's death in October of 1971.  As both a singer and composer as well, he was central to the group's greatest commercial success in the mid-1970s and was the writer and vocalist on the Allmans' hit single "[[Ramblin' Man (The Allman Brothers Band song)|Ramblin' Man]]". 

Early in his career Betts was best noted for collaboration with Duane Allman,<ref name=Tdrozodowski>{{cite web|url=http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/Features/Come%20and%20Go%20Blues_%20The%20Incredi|title=Come and Go Blues: The Incredible Guitarists of the Allman Brothers|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100126202416/http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/Features/Come%20and%20Go%20Blues_%20The%20Incredi|archive-date=January 26, 2010}}</ref> the twosome introducing melodic twin guitar harmony and counterpoint, which, according to ''Guitar World'' "rewrote the rules for how two rock guitarists can work together, completely scrapping the traditional rhythm/lead roles to stand toe to toe".<ref name="GW July 2009">{{cite magazine|title=The Allman Brothers Band: The Road Goes on Forever|magazine=Guitar World|date=July 20, 2009|url=http://www.guitarworld.com/article/the_allman_brothers_band_the_road_goes_on_forever|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100202053024/http://www.guitarworld.com/article/the_allman_brothers_band_the_road_goes_on_forever|archive-date=February 2, 2010}}</ref> Betts initially gained renown for his epic [[instrumental]], "[[In Memory of Elizabeth Reed]]", from the Band's second album, ''[[Idlewild South]]'', followed by his striking guitar duet-driven "[[Blue Sky (song)|Blue Sky]]", which not only was his first band vocal but signaled a dramatic new sound and potential direction for it.  

In the wake of Duane's death the group indeed followed both Betts' musical direction and band leadership, exploding into commercial success in 1973 upon the introduction of the [[Country music|Country]]-influenced ''[[Brothers and Sisters (album)|Brothers and Sisters]]'', and the chart success of its catchy Betts-written hits, exuberant "Ramblin' Man" and the melodic instrumental "[[Jessica (instrumental)|Jessica]]".

The band went through a hiatus in the late 1970s, during which time Betts, like many of the other band members, pursued a solo career and side projects under such names as Great Southern and The Dickey Betts Band.  The Allman Brothers reformed in 1979, with [[Dan Toler]] taking the second guitar role alongside Betts.  In 1982, it broke up a second time, during which break Betts formed the group [[Betts, Hall, Leavell and Trucks]], which lasted until 1984.  A third reformation occurred in 1989, with [[Warren Haynes]] then joining Betts on guitar. 

Betts was ousted from the band in 2000 over a conflict regarding his continued drug and alcohol abuse; he never played with them again, nor would he appear with other former band members for reunions or side projects. With the death of Betts on April 18, 2024, Jai Johanny "[[Jaimoe]]" Johanson is the last living founding member of the Allman Brothers Band.

He was inducted with the band into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] in 1995<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=http://www.rockhall.com/inductees/the-allman-brothers-band/ |title=The Allman Brothers Band: inducted in 1995 &#124; The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum |publisher=Rockhall.com |access-date=February 28, 2012 |archive-date=July 1, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120701000000/http://www.rockhall.com/inductees/the-allman-brothers-band/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and also won a best rock performance [[Grammy Award]] with the band for "Jessica" in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=&title=&year=1995&genre=All|title=1995 Grammy Award Winners|publisher=Grammy.com|access-date=November 18, 2012|archive-date=September 23, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120923073524/http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=&title=&year=1995&genre=All|url-status=live}}</ref> Betts was ranked No. 58 on ''Rolling Stone''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time list in 2003, and No. 61 on the list published in 2011.<ref name=RS931>{{cite magazine |title=The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time |magazine=Rolling Stone |issue=931 |date=September 22, 2003 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-of-all-time-19691231/dickey-betts-19691231 |access-date=August 26, 2017 |archive-date=July 13, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120713073551/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-of-all-time-19691231/dickey-betts-19691231 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=RS1145>{{cite magazine|title=The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time|magazine=Rolling Stone|issue=1145|date=November 23, 2011|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-20111123/dickey-betts-19691231|access-date=August 26, 2017|archive-date=July 18, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718093137/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-20111123/dickey-betts-19691231|url-status=live}}</ref>

== Early life ==
{{expand section|date=September 2024}}

Betts was born in [[West Palm Beach, Florida]], on December 12, 1943, and raised in [[Bradenton, Florida|Bradenton]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lcwXAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT69|title=Skydog: The Duane Allman Story|first=Randy|last=Poe|date=August 1, 2008|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation|isbn=9781617134876}}</ref><ref name=NFMHOF>{{cite web|last1=Fitzgerald|first1=Michael|title=Betts, Dickey|url=http://nfmhof.com/2008/08/13/betts-dickey|publisher=North Florida Music Hall of Fame|access-date=August 3, 2014|date=August 13, 2008|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108154840/http://nfmhof.com/2008/08/13/betts-dickey|archive-date=November 8, 2014}}</ref> He grew up in a musical family listening to [[traditional bluegrass]], [[country music]] and [[Western swing]]. He started playing ukulele at the age of five and, as his hands got bigger, moved on to mandolin, banjo, and guitar.

==Career==
By the age of sixteen Betts was feeling the need for something "a little faster", and played in a series of rock bands on the Florida circuit, up the East Coast and into the Midwest.  In 1967 he formed the Second Coming in Florida with [[Berry Oakley]]. According to its composer, [[Rick Derringer]], the group called the Jokers referenced in "[[Rock and Roll, Hoochie Koo]]" was one of Betts' early groups of that name.<ref>Scott Freeman, ''Midnight Riders'', pp. 41–42</ref>

=== Early Allman Brothers Band years ===
In 1969, [[Duane Allman]], a veteran of the South's "Chitlin' Circuit" of roadhouses and small local venues who'd gone on to form several bands with recording contracts, was casting for talent to build another around.  A successful session player, he'd gained a deal with [[Southern soul]] impresario [[Phil Walden]], who planned to back a [[power trio]] featuring Allman. The ensuing Allman Brothers Band eventually grew to six members, including Duane's brother, organist, vocalist, and composer [[Gregg Allman|Gregg]], Betts, and bassist [[Berry Oakley]].{{cn|date=April 2024}} Duane, who later worked with famed British guitar virtuoso [[Eric Clapton]], earning notoriety for his standout playing on "[[Layla (song)|Layla]]'', the collaboration's signature hit, once said with typical modesty, "I'm the famous guitar player, but Dickey is the good one."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Alex |title=Dickey Betts, Fiery Guitarist With Allman Brothers Band, Dies at 80 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/04/18/arts/music/dickey-betts-dead.html |work=The New York Times |date=April 18, 2024 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |archive-date=April 19, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240419202131/https://www.nytimes.com/2024/04/18/arts/music/dickey-betts-dead.html |url-status=live }}</ref> 

After Allman's death in October 1971, Betts became the band's sole lead guitarist (with a pianist bringing the group back up to six members) and took on a greater singing, composing, and leadership role. Rushed into the role, he practiced [[slide guitar]] intensively in order to be able to cover the majority of Duane's parts. He wrote "[[Jessica (Allman Brothers Band song)|Jessica]]", inspired by his young daughter Jessica,<ref>{{Cite book|title=One Way Out: The Inside History of the Allman Brothers Band|first=Alan|last=Paul|year=2014|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn=978-1250040497}}</ref>and the Allmans' biggest commercial hit, "[[Ramblin' Man (Allman Brothers Band song)|Ramblin' Man]]",<ref>{{cite web|url= https://rockcellarmagazine.com/dickey-betts-dies-allman-brothers-band-obituary/|title=Dickey Betts, Allman Brothers Co-Founder Who Wrote "Ramblin' Man," "Jessica" and More, Dies at 80|publisher=Rockcellarmagazine.com|date=April 18, 2024|accessdate=April 20, 2024}}</ref> for the Band's breakout commercial success, ''[[Brothers and Sisters (album)|Brothers and Sisters]]'', in 1974.

=== Solo career and later work ===
[[File:Dickey Betts (1974).jpg|thumb|Betts in 1974|244x244px]]
Betts's first solo album, ''[[Highway Call]]'', was released in 1974 and featured fiddle player [[Vassar Clements]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Highway Call – Dickey Betts, Richard Betts &#124; Album &#124; AllMus |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/highway-call-mw0000199122 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221022115912/https://www.allmusic.com/album/highway-call-mw0000199122 |archive-date=October 22, 2022 |access-date=April 19, 2024 |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> After the Allman Brothers fell apart in 1976, Betts released more albums, starting with ''[[Dickey Betts & Great Southern (album)|Dickey Betts & Great Southern]]'' in 1977, which included the song "Bougainvillea", co-written with future Hollywood star and then Florida transplant [[Don Johnson]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Dickey Betts & Great Southern – Dickey Betts & Great Southe |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/dickey-betts-great-southern-mw0000602906 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230909051526/https://www.allmusic.com/album/dickey-betts-great-southern-mw0000602906 |archive-date=September 9, 2023 |access-date=April 19, 2024 |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> In 1978 he released an album, ''[[Atlanta's Burning Down]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Atlanta's Burning Down – Dickey Betts &#124; Album &#124; AllMusic |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/atlantas-burning-down-mw0000049199 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221020100419/https://www.allmusic.com/album/atlantas-burning-down-mw0000049199 |archive-date=October 20, 2022 |access-date=April 19, 2024 |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref>

The Allman Brothers reformed in 1979 for the album ''[[Enlightened Rogues]]'', with two members of Great Southern replacing Allman Brothers members who were unwilling to participate in the reunion: guitar player [[Dan Toler]] for pianist [[Chuck Leavell]], and bassist [[David Goldflies]] for bassist [[Lamar Williams]]. Several albums and personnel changes followed, until declining record and concert ticket sales, personnel issues, and management problems led the group to disband again in 1982.<ref>{{Cite web |date=October 27, 2014 |title=History of the Allman Brothers Band |url=https://ultimateclassicrock.com/allman-brothers-band-history/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231003172943/https://ultimateclassicrock.com/allman-brothers-band-history/ |archive-date=October 3, 2023 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |publisher=Ultimateclassicrock.com}}</ref>

Betts formed his own band, [[Betts, Hall, Leavell and Trucks]], where he was co-frontman along with former [[Wet Willie]] singer, saxophone, and harmonica player [[Jimmy Hall]]. Despite earning good notices, the group was unable to secure a recording contract and disbanded in 1984.<ref>{{Cite book |last1=Leavell |first1=Chuck |title=Between Rock And A Home Place |last2=Craig |first2=J. Marshall |publisher=Evergreen Arts |year=2004 |isbn=0-86554-975-3 |location=Dry Branch, Georgia |pages=260–264}} For the ending year, see {{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/101951915/lexington-herald-leader/ | title=David Goldflies' jazz vision | author-first=Walter | author-last=Tunis | newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader | date=April 21, 1991 | pages=C1, C7 | via=Newspapers.com | access-date=May 21, 2022 | archive-date=May 20, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220520105254/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/101951915/lexington-herald-leader/ | url-status=live }}</ref> Betts  returned to his solo career performing live at smaller venues, and released the album ''Pattern Disruptive'' in 1989. When a one-off reunion tour was proposed in support of the Allman Brothers' ''[[Dreams (The Allman Brothers Band album)|Dreams]]'' box set, released in 1989 to commemorate the band's 20th anniversary, Betts's solo band again supplied the Allman Brothers' other lead guitarist, [[Warren Haynes]]. The success of the one-off tour resulted in a permanent reunion, which absorbed Betts's energies for the remainder of the 1990s. This band line-up released three studio albums between 1990 and 1994 and won the praise of the critics.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Elliott, Mike |date=July 20, 2020 |title=The Allman Brothers Band's 'Seven Turns' Turns 30 {{!}} Anniversary Retrospective |url=https://albumism.com/features/the-allman-brothers-band-seven-turns-turns-30-anniversary-retrospective |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220703150058/https://albumism.com/features/the-allman-brothers-band-seven-turns-turns-30-anniversary-retrospective |archive-date=July 3, 2022 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |publisher=Albumism}}</ref>
[[File:Dickey Betts Pistoia Blues Festival 2008.jpg|left|thumb|243x243px|Betts in 2008]]
Betts was replaced on numerous Allman Brothers tour dates throughout the mid-to-late 1990s, for what were reported in the media as "personal reasons". While remaining active as a touring band, the Allman Brothers did not release another album of studio material after 1994's ''[[Where It All Begins]]'' for nine years, until ''[[Hittin' the Note]]'' in 2003. In 1994, Haynes and Allmans bassist Allen Woody formed [[Gov't Mule]] with former Dickey Betts Band drummer Matt Abts as a side project, and left the Allman Brothers for Gov't Mule full-time in 1997. Betts' last show with the Allman Brothers was at the Music Midtown Festival in [[Atlanta, Georgia]], on May 7, 2000.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Roger Catlin |date=May 25, 2000 |title=BETTS IS ANGRY AS ALLMANS DUMP HIM FROM TOUR |url=https://www.courant.com/news/connecticut/hc-xpm-2000-05-25-0005251999-story.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190720154255/https://www.courant.com/news/connecticut/hc-xpm-2000-05-25-0005251999-story.html |archive-date=July 20, 2019 |access-date=February 3, 2021 |website=Courant.com}}</ref>

A breaking point was reached after that show and before the launch of the band's Summer Campaign Tour when the remaining original Allman Brothers members – Gregg Allman, Butch Trucks, and Jaimoe – suspended Betts.<ref name="ew">{{Cite magazine |last=Reese |first=Lori |date=May 18, 2000 |title=Brothers in Law |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,85221,00.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021145418/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,85221,00.html |archive-date=October 21, 2012 |access-date=June 16, 2011 |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]}}</ref> According to Betts, the band told him (reportedly via [[fax]]) to "get clean" (from alcohol and/or drugs). 

He was temporarily replaced for the 2000 tour by [[Jimmy Herring]], formerly of the [[Aquarium Rescue Unit]]. When Betts filed suit against the other three original Allmans, the separation turned into a permanent divorce.<ref>{{cite book |last=Allman |first=Gregg |title=My Cross To Bear |publisher=HarperCollins |year=2012}}{{p.|340}}</ref> Betts re-formed the Dickey Betts Band and toured that same summer. The band reassumed the name Dickey Betts & Great Southern and added Betts' son Duane (named after Duane Allman) on lead guitar. In 2005, Betts released the DVD ''Live from the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Back Where It All Begins: Live at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame [Video] |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/back-where-it-all-begins-live-at-the-rock-and-roll-hall-of-fame-video--mw0001020587 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |publisher=AllMusic}}</ref>

Although they had been separated personally and as musical bandmates for over 15 years, Betts and Gregg Allman became reconciled before Allman's death in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Ferris, Jedd |date=December 13, 2018 |title=ee Dickey Betts Talk Gregg Allman Reconciliation, Return to Touring |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/dickey-betts-allman-brothers-dan-rather-768633/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230606131632/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/dickey-betts-allman-brothers-dan-rather-768633/ |archive-date=June 6, 2023 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |publisher=Rolling Stone}}</ref>

Betts' final album release was ''Dickey Betts & Great Southern Official Bootleg Vol. 1'' (2021), a two-CD live album of performances from the 2000s.<ref>{{Cite news |date=April 24, 2021 |title=Dickey Betts Announces 'Dickey Betts & Great Southern Official Bootleg Vol. 1' |url=https://dickeybetts.com/dickey-betts-announces-dickey-betts-great-southern-official-bootleg-vol-1/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240109192901/https://dickeybetts.com/dickey-betts-announces-dickey-betts-great-southern-official-bootleg-vol-1/ |archive-date=January 9, 2024 |access-date=April 18, 2024 |work=Dickey Betts}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Betts was married five times, last to Donna, in 1989.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/dickey-betts-the-lost-allman-brother-121021/|title=Dickey Betts Looks Back: The Lost Allman Brother on Regret, Retirement|last=Browne|first=David|date=November 22, 2017|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|access-date=February 18, 2020|archive-date=February 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200218202725/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/dickey-betts-the-lost-allman-brother-121021/|url-status=live}}</ref> He had four children: Kimberly, Christy, Jessica, and [[Duane Betts|Duane]]. Christy is married to [[Frank Hannon]] of the band [[Tesla (band)|Tesla]]. Jessica is the namesake of Betts' [[Jessica (instrumental) |instrumental]]. Duane, named for Betts' former bandmate Duane Allman, is also a musician and performed and recorded with his father, and in a band together with Gregg Allman's son Devon.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.heraldtribune.com/news/20180809/duane-betts-talks-album-with-devon-allman-dickey-betts-band-live-cddvd-and-aug-15-sarasota-show|title=Duane Betts talks album with Devon Allman, Dickey Betts Band live CD/DVD and Aug. 15 Sarasota show|last=Tatangelo|first=Wade|website=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|language=en|access-date=February 18, 2020|archive-date=September 29, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190929154356/https://www.heraldtribune.com/news/20180809/duane-betts-talks-album-with-devon-allman-dickey-betts-band-live-cddvd-and-aug-15-sarasota-show|url-status=live}}</ref>

Betts was a Florida native, born in [[West Palm Beach]]; though he resided briefly in Georgia during the formative years of the Allman Brothers Band, he lived in the [[Sarasota metropolitan area]] for most of his life.<ref>{{cite web|author=Paul Liberatore|url=http://www.marinij.com/marinnews/ci_20957654/lib-at-large-duane-betts-and-legacy-allman|title=Lib at Large: Duane Betts and the legacy of the Allman Brothers|work=[[Marin Independent Journal]]|publisher=Marinij.com|date=June 29, 2012|access-date=July 11, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714210135/http://www.marinij.com/marinnews/ci_20957654/lib-at-large-duane-betts-and-legacy-allman|archive-date=July 14, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref>

===Death===
In August 2018, the 74-year old Betts suffered a mild stroke and had to cancel tour dates with his Dickey Betts Band. He was taken to the hospital and was in a critical but stable condition at a Florida hospital, following an accident at his home in [[Osprey, Florida]]. On September 20, 2018,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/music/news/dickey-betts-to-undergo-brain-surgery-following-accident/ar-BBNzI1x|title=Dickey Betts to Undergo Brain Surgery Following Accident|website=www.msn.com|language=en-US|access-date=September 20, 2018|archive-date=September 20, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180920084332/https://www.msn.com/en-us/music/news/dickey-betts-to-undergo-brain-surgery-following-accident/ar-BBNzI1x|url-status=live}}</ref> he successfully underwent surgery to relieve swelling on his brain. In a statement posted on his website, Betts and his family said the "outpouring of support from all over the world has been overwhelming and amazing. We are so appreciative."<ref>{{cite web|author=Tatangelo, Wade|url=https://eu.news-journalonline.com/story/news/state/2018/09/22/dickey-betts-surgery-success-in/10366942007/|title=Dickey Betts' surgery a 'success' in Sarasota|publisher=The Daytona Bach News Journal|date=September 18, 2018|accessdate=April 20, 2024}}</ref>

Betts died from cancer and [[chronic obstructive pulmonary disease]] at his home in Osprey, Florida, on April 18, 2024, at the age of 80.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dickey Betts, Allman Brothers Band Singer-Guitarist, Dead at 80|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/dickey-betts-allman-brothers-band-dead-727523/|last=Browne|first=David|publisher=Rolling Stone|date=April 18, 2024|access-date=April 18, 2024|archive-date=April 18, 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240418154924/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/dickey-betts-allman-brothers-band-dead-727523/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Instagram |url=https://www.instagram.com/p/C56GswQuAKR/ |access-date=April 18, 2024 |website=www.instagram.com |archive-date=April 18, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240418160858/https://www.instagram.com/p/C56GswQuAKR/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

'''Kenneth Eric Church''' (born May 3, 1977) is an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter. He has released nine studio albums through [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]] since 2005. His debut album, 2006's ''[[Sinners Like Me]]'', produced three singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts including the top 20 hits "[[How 'Bout You]]", "[[Two Pink Lines]]", and "[[Guys Like Me]]".

His second album, 2009's ''[[Carolina (Eric Church album)|Carolina]]'', produced three more singles: "[[Smoke a Little Smoke]]" and his first top 10 hits, "[[Love Your Love the Most]]" and "[[Hell on the Heart]]". 2011's ''[[Chief (album)|Chief]]'', his first No. 1 album, gave him his first two No. 1 singles, "[[Drink in My Hand]]" and "[[Springsteen (song)|Springsteen]]", and the hits "[[Homeboy (Eric Church song)|Homeboy]]", "[[Creepin' (Eric Church song)|Creepin']]", and "[[Like Jesus Does]]". His third No. 1 single was "[[The Only Way I Know]]", which he, [[Jason Aldean]], and [[Luke Bryan]] recorded for Aldean's album ''[[Night Train (Jason Aldean album)|Night Train]]''.

A fourth album, ''[[The Outsiders (Eric Church album)|The Outsiders]]'', was released in February 2014. It produced five new singles between 2013 and 2015 with the [[The Outsiders (Eric Church song)|title track]], "[[Give Me Back My Hometown]]", "[[Cold One]]", "[[Talladega (song)|Talladega]]" and "[[Like a Wrecking Ball]]". "Talladega" and "Give Me Back My Hometown" each reached number one on the [[Country Airplay]] chart. Eric Church got his sixth No. 1 hit with [[Keith Urban]] in May 2015 with the single "[[Raise 'Em Up]]". His fifth studio album, ''[[Mr. Misunderstood]]'', was released in November 2015 and went on to produce two number one singles with "[[Record Year]]" and "[[Round Here Buzz]]". On July 13, 2018, Church released the first single and [[Desperate Man (song)|title track]] of his album ''[[Desperate Man (album)|Desperate Man]]'', which was released in October 2018. In April 2021, Church released the [[triple album]] set ''[[Heart & Soul (Eric Church album)|Heart & Soul]]''.

==Early life==
Church was born on May 3, 1977, in [[Granite Falls, North Carolina]] (Dudley Shoals area), to Ken and Rita Church. Church worked with his father at Clayton Marcus, a furniture upholstery company where his father was president.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.furnituretoday.com/article/519425-pulaski-plans-eric-church-furniture-line|title=Pulaski plans Eric Church furniture line - Furniture Today|website=Furnituretoday.com|date=8 May 2015|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref> At 13, he bought a guitar and began writing songs of his own. By his senior year of high school, he had found a gig at a local bar, which occupied most of his time. He played many [[Jimmy Buffett]] cover songs and a few of his own original songs in some dive bars. Some of these places were so rough that he got into a few altercations from the stage. For a few years, the band played often in bars and restaurants throughout North Carolina.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} The band "Mountain Boys" consisted of his college roommate, brother, and a fellow guitarist.<ref name="allmusic" />

Before moving to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], Eric graduated from [[South Caldwell High School]] and then [[Appalachian State University]] with a degree in [[marketing]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/301808/eric-church/biography |title=Eric Church biography
|magazine=Billboard
|access-date=2016-07-17 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820212033/http://www.billboard.com/artist/301808/eric-church/biography |archive-date=2016-08-20 }}</ref> Upon graduation, Church became engaged to a [[Spanish language|Spanish]] teacher in the town of [[Lenoir, North Carolina]]. The future bride's father attempted to persuade Church into a corporate career, which he rejected as an aspiring musician (and later referenced in his song "What I Almost Was" from his debut album). She broke the engagement and he headed to Nashville with his father's financial backing. His father also provided the opportunity to make contacts, and more importantly, time to focus on developing his songwriting ability.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}}

==Music career==
===2006–2010: ''Sinners Like Me'' and ''Carolina''===
Church co-wrote [[Terri Clark]]'s 2005 single "The World Needs a Drink",<ref name="allmusic" /> and the track "Whiskey Wings" on [[Dean Miller]]'s 2005 album ''[[Platinum (Dean Miller album)|Platinum]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/platinum-mw0000208385|title=''Platinum'' review|last=Deming|first=Mark|work=Allmusic|access-date=29 August 2012}}</ref> He started recording with different producers. Capitol Nashville showed an interest and watched him perform but they were yet to be convinced enough to offer a recording contract.<ref name="hitquarters">{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_AutumnH.html |title=Interview with Autumn House-Tallant |publisher=[[HitQuarters]] | date=3 Oct 2011 |access-date=6 October 2011}}</ref> Autumn House-Tallant told [[HitQuarters]] that they did not think his music was "interesting" enough.<ref name="hitquarters" /> The record company's attitude changed after he started working with producer [[Jay Joyce]]. Doyle states, "Eric scored a meeting with Nashville heavyweight Arthur Buenahora, a publisher at Sony Music who also signed [[Taylor Swift]] and [[Miranda Lambert]]. Church played him "Lightning", a ballad he wrote after watching the movie ''The Green Mile''". (p. 5) The strong sound and direction the two forged together finally convinced Capitol Nashville that he was ready.<ref name="hitquarters" /> His first single, "[[How 'Bout You]]" peaked at No. 14 on [[Hot Country Songs]] and led off his debut album ''[[Sinners Like Me]]''. In April 2006, he performed on the [[Grand Ole Opry]] for the first time.<ref name="cmtsinners">{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1537741/eric-church-turns-heads-with-sinners-like-me.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607034411/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1537741/eric-church-turns-heads-with-sinners-like-me.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 7, 2011|title=Church Turns Heads With ''Sinners Like Me''|last=Morris|first=Edward|date=2006-08-02|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]] | access-date=5 December 2009}}</ref>

The album's other two singles, "[[Two Pink Lines]]" and "[[Guys Like Me]]", both reached the Top 20 as well.<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p816669/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Eric Church biography|last=Ruhlmann|first=William|work=[[Allmusic]] | access-date=2008-12-27}}</ref> The fourth single, the title track, peaked at No. 51. An additional track from the album, "Lightning", was made into a [[music video]] despite not being released as a single. Church wrote the song shortly after moving to Nashville, inspired by the movie ''[[The Green Mile (film)|The Green Mile]]''.<ref name="cmtsinners" /> Following the album's success, Church toured with [[Brad Paisley]] and [[Rascal Flatts]].<ref name="cmtsinners" /> Church was fired from opening for Rascal Flatts after repeatedly performing for longer than his allotted time, despite repeated warnings. He was replaced by Taylor Swift, who was just starting her career. Before Swift started the tour, Church and Swift spoke, where he told Swift that she would thrive on the tour and joked that she should give him her first gold record as a thanks. Swift later did give him her first gold record with an attached note that said "Thanks for playing too long and too loud on the Flatts tour. I sincerely appreciate it. Taylor".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-rascal-flatts-tour-taylor-swift-secret-history/|title=How Eric Church's Rascal Flatts Feud Helped Launch Taylor Swift|first=Sterling WhitakerAnia|last=Hammar|website=Taste of Country|date=27 May 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/remember-when-taylor-swift-eric-church-gold-record/|title=Remember When Taylor Swift Gave Eric Church Her First Gold Record?|first=Billy|last=Dukes|website=Taste of Country|date=18 August 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tucson.com/entertainment/blogs/caliente-tuned-in/eric-church-s-taylor-swift-story/article_61cb6c52-5bd1-11e0-88bd-001cc4c002e0.html|title=Eric Church's Taylor Swift story|first=Cathalena E. Burch Arizona Daily|last=Star|website=Arizona Daily Star|date=31 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theboot.com/rascal-flatts-eric-church-fired-tour/|title=Rascal Flatts Comment on Firing Eric Church From Their Tour|first=Gayle|last=Thompson|website=The Boot|date=4 February 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theboot.com/eric-church-rascal-flatts-tour-secret-history-of-country-music/|title=Eric Church Deliberately Pushed Rascal Flatts' Buttons During 2006 Tour|first=Carena|last=Liptak|website=The Boot|date=27 May 2019 }}</ref>

In 2008, Church released a fifth single, "His Kind of Money (My Kind of Love)" to country radio. It debuted on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart at No. 55 in early 2008, and reached its peak of No. 46 in August. Originally slated as the lead single to an upcoming second album, "His Kind of Money" was instead included as a bonus track on albums sold at Best Buy. Following this song was "[[Love Your Love the Most]]", which debuted in early 2009 and was the first single from his second album ''[[Carolina (Eric Church album)|Carolina]]'', released in stores on March 24, 2009.<ref name="allmusic" /> The night before the official release, Church and Capitol Records distributed copies of the album on the campus of Church's alma mater, Appalachian State University, during a "release party" concert.<ref name="goblueridge.net">{{cite web | url = http://www.goblueridge.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5967&catid=1&Itemid=155 | title = Eric Church to Hold Album Release Party in Boone. | access-date = 2012-09-19 | url-status=dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130130075804/http://www.goblueridge.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5967&catid=1&Itemid=155 | archive-date = 2013-01-30 }}</ref> As with his debut album, ''Carolina'' was produced by Jay Joyce, and is entirely composed of songs that he co-wrote. "Love Your Love the Most" brought Church to the top 10 for the very first time, peaking at No. 10 in September 2009. The album's second single, "[[Hell on the Heart]]", debuted in October 2009 and would also hit the top 10 in May 2010. The third single from "Carolina" was "[[Smoke a Little Smoke]]". In June 2010, Church moved to Capitol Nashville's new imprint EMI Records Nashville, becoming their second artist. On January 14, 2011, he released a four-song EP entitled ''Caldwell County''.

===2011–2015: ''Chief'' and ''The Outsiders''===
[[File:Eric Church 2012 Cropped 2.jpg|thumb|alt=Photo of Eric Church on stage|Church performing live at GNA's Countryfest at the Times Union Center, Albany, New York, July 7, 2012]]
Church released "[[Homeboy (Eric Church song)|Homeboy]]" to country radio in early 2011. The album ''[[Chief (album)|Chief]]'', produced by Jay Joyce, was released July 26, 2011, debuting at No. 1 on both [[Top Country Albums]] and the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref name="Album source">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/468392/eric-church-lands-first-no-1-album-amy-winehouse-continues-to-climb|title=Eric Church Lands First No. 1 Album, Amy Winehouse Climbs Into Top 5|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | access-date=August 3, 2011}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite magazine|title = The Billboard Cover Story – The Gospel According to Eric Church: Thinking Global| magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |url = https://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/5812226/the-billboard-cover-story-the-gospel-according-to-eric-church-thinking|access-date = 2015-10-03}}</ref> The album sold 145,000 copies in its first week.<ref name="Album source" /> On November 30, 2011, ''Chief'' was announced as a nominee for the 2012 Grammy Awards for Best Country Album. In January 2012 "Drink in My Hand" became his first No. 1 single. In February 2012, "[[Springsteen (song)|Springsteen]]" was released as the third single from ''Chief''. In an interview with [[American Songwriter]], Church stated that the song was about "a love affair that takes place in an amphitheater between two people. It didn't happen with Springsteen, ironically, it happened with another artist."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2012/06/eric-church-springsteen/ |title=Eric Church, "Springsteen" |last=Giles |first=Jeff |date=11 June 2012 |publisher=American Songwriter |access-date=2012-06-11}}</ref> The song went on to become a No. 1 country hit, as well as his first Top 20 single on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. The album's fourth single, "[[Creepin' (Eric Church song)|Creepin']]", was released to country radio on July 16, 2012. Church lent his vocals for a song titled, "[[The Only Way I Know]]", with [[Jason Aldean]] along [[Luke Bryan]]. This song appears on Aldean's album ''[[Night Train (Jason Aldean album)|Night Train]]'', from which it was released as the second single. The fifth single from ''Chief'', "[[Like Jesus Does]]", was released in January 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-like-jesus-does/ |title=Eric Church, 'Like Jesus Does' – Song Review |publisher=Taste of Country |access-date=February 13, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302131929/http://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-like-jesus-does/ |archive-date=March 2, 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref> and peaked at number six on [[Country Airplay]] chart in June 2013.

In September 2012, Church announced that he planned to release his first live album in 2013, containing recordings of performances at the [[Tivoli Theatre (Chattanooga, Tennessee)|Tivoli Theatre]] in Chattanooga, Tennessee, on October 8 and 9, 2012.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.theboot.com/2012/09/04/eric-church-live-album/ | title=Eric Church Live Album to Hit Stores in 2013 | publisher=The Boot | date=September 4, 2012 | access-date=December 15, 2012}}</ref> On February 8, the live album's title was announced as ''Caught in the Act'', with a release date set for April 9.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-caught-in-the-act-release-date/ |title=Eric Church Announces Release Date for First Live Album, 'Caught in the Act' |publisher=Taste of Country |date=February 8, 2013 |access-date=February 13, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130213083413/http://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-caught-in-the-act-release-date/ |archive-date=February 13, 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref>  Church has stated he plans to take some time off from music in 2013 to focus on his songwriting and musical direction.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.charlestoncitypaper.com/charleston/eric-church-rebels-against-the-music-city-machine/Content?oid=4246798 |title=Eric Church rebels against the Music City machine |publisher=Charleston City Paper |date=December 12, 2012 |access-date=December 15, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121215011233/http://www.charlestoncitypaper.com/charleston/eric-church-rebels-against-the-music-city-machine/Content?oid=4246798 |archive-date=December 15, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> At the 2012 CMA Awards in November, Church's album ''[[Chief (album)|Chief]]'' won Album of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-album-of-the-year-2012-cma-awards/ |title=Eric Church Finally Finds His Niche, Wins Album of the Year Award at 2012 CMAs |publisher=Taste of Country |date=November 1, 2012 |access-date=December 15, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130109050200/http://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-album-of-the-year-2012-cma-awards/ |archive-date=January 9, 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In November it was announced that Church would co-headline [[Kenny Chesney]]'s No Shoes Nation Tour alongside Chesney, [[Zac Brown Band]], and [[Eli Young Band]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/kenny-chesney-2013-tour-no-shoes-nation/ |title=Kenny Chesney Announces 2013 No Shoes Nation Tour |publisher=Taste of Country |date=November 8, 2012 |access-date=December 15, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115154253/http://tasteofcountry.com/kenny-chesney-2013-tour-no-shoes-nation/ |archive-date=November 15, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In December, Eric was honored as one of the CMT Artists of the Year Awards. His award was presented by [[Kid Rock]] and he received a video message of congratulations from [[Metallica]]'s [[James Hetfield]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1698588/2012-cmt-artists-year-revealed.jhtml |title=2012 CMT Artists of the Year Revealed |website=MTV.com |date=December 9, 2012 |access-date=December 15, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121212062555/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1698588/2012-cmt-artists-year-revealed.jhtml |archive-date=December 12, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

On October 22, 2013, Church released a new single titled "[[The Outsiders (Eric Church song)|The Outsiders]]". His fourth studio album, also titled ''[[The Outsiders (Eric Church album)|The Outsiders]]'', was released on February 11, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last=Talbott|first=Chris|title=Eric Church set to drop new album, 'The Outsiders,' blow minds at CMAs with metal moment|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/music/eric-church-set-to-drop-new-album-the-outsiders-blow-minds-at-cmas-with-metal-moment/2013/11/04/1bb43982-4554-11e3-95a9-3f15b5618ba8_story.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105034627/http://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/music/eric-church-set-to-drop-new-album-the-outsiders-blow-minds-at-cmas-with-metal-moment/2013/11/04/1bb43982-4554-11e3-95a9-3f15b5618ba8_story.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=November 5, 2013|access-date=November 5, 2013|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] | date=November 4, 2013}}</ref> This album, as with Church's previous three, was produced by Jay Joyce and released on the EMI Records Nashville label.<ref name=":0" /> It was followed in January 2014 by "[[Give Me Back My Hometown]]". This single reached number one on the [[Country Airplay]] chart, becoming his fourth overall. The third single, "[[Cold One]]", was released in June 2014, followed by "[[Talladega (song)|Talladega]]" in September. The latter reached number one on the Country Airplay chart in February 2015. The fifth single, "[[Like a Wrecking Ball]]", was released to country radio on March 9, 2015.

===2015–2018: ''Mr. Misunderstood'' and ''Desperate Man''===
On November 3, 2015, Church's new surprise album, ''[[Mr. Misunderstood]]'', arrived in the mailboxes of his fan club members. The album became available to the public on iTunes the following day. The album was released as a surprise with no fanfare and no promotional advertisements. It was produced by Jay Joyce and executive producer Arturo Buenahora Jr. The first single, the [[Mr. Misunderstood (song)|title track]], was released to radio on November 9, 2015. The first live performance and debut of the track was at the 2015 CMA Awards. The song peaked at No. 15 on the airplay chart on February 6, 2016.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/301808/eric-church/chart?f%3D1244 |title=Eric Church - Chart history &#124; Billboard |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2016-02-04 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160402033558/http://www.billboard.com/artist/301808/eric-church/chart?f=1244 |archive-date=2016-04-02}}</ref> "[[Record Year (song)|Record Year]]" is the album's second single. The album's final track, "Three Year Old", pays tribute to all the lessons Church has learned from his three-year-old son, who was also credited with naming Church's guitar "ButterBean". Church used "ButterBean" for the creation of the album.<ref>{{Cite magazine|title = Eric Church Releases Surprise Album 'Mr. Misunderstood'|url = https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/eric-church-releases-surprise-album-mr-misunderstood-20151104|magazine = Rolling Stone|date = 4 November 2015|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> ''[[Mr. Misunderstood]]'' was nominated for Album of the Year at the 2016 [[ACM Awards]] and the [[Mr. Misunderstood (song)|title track]] was nominated for Video of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Eric Church leads the 2016 ACM Awards with 5 nominations – Eric Church|url = http://ericchurch.com/news/382683/eric-church-leads-the-2016-acm-awards-with-5-nomin|website = Eric Church|access-date = 2016-02-07|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160208011916/http://ericchurch.com/news/382683/eric-church-leads-the-2016-acm-awards-with-5-nomin|archive-date = 2016-02-08|url-status = dead}}</ref> ''[[Mr. Misunderstood]]'' features ten self-written and co-written tracks and features themes of independence, lessons learned, and loyalty. The album was recorded by Jason Hall at St. Charles in Nashville. In March 2016, "Record Year" was released to radio; it reached No. 1 on the Country Airplay in August 2016. The album's third single, "[[Kill a Word]]" released to country radio on August 29, 2016. Church was selected as one of 30 artists to perform on "Forever Country", a mash-up track of "[[Take Me Home, Country Roads]]", "[[On the Road Again (Willie Nelson song)|On the Road Again]]" and "[[I Will Always Love You]]" which celebrates 50 years of the [[CMA Awards]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/scenes-cmas-historic-music-video-featuring-30-country/story?id%3D42129062 |title=30 Country Music Stars Join Forces for Historic CMA Music Video, 'Forever Country' - ABC News |website=[[ABC News (United States)|ABC News]] |access-date=2016-09-17 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161115165209/http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/scenes-cmas-historic-music-video-featuring-30-country/story?id=42129062 |archive-date=2016-11-15 }}</ref>

Church played his biggest solo tour to date with his Holdin' My Own Tour that featured 62 shows in 61 cities from January through May 2017. The tour was capped off by two sold-out shows at Nashville's [[Bridgestone Arena]], with the Friday night show breaking the arena's capacity record before being one-upped by the Saturday night show which set of record of 19,020 attendees.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2017/05/28/eric-church-ends-tour-record-breaking-nashville-concert/347139001/ |title=Eric Church ends tour with record-breaking Nashville concert |website=[[The Tennessean]] |access-date=2018-07-14 }}</ref> On October 4, 2017, Church debuted a song he had written for Sonny Melton, who died in the [[2017 Las Vegas shooting|Las Vegas shooting]] tragedy. The song, called "Why Not Me", was performed at the Grand Ole Opry in Nashville.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kelley|first1=Caitlin|title=Eric Church Debuts New Song Dedicated to Las Vegas Shooting Victims at Grand Ole Opry|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/7989432/eric-church-new-song-las-vegas-shooting-victims-grand-ole-opry-show-video|access-date=11 October 2017|publisher=Billboard|date=5 October 2017}}</ref> In November 2017 Church released a limited run vinyl box set titled ''61 Days in Church'' that would be released in monthly stages through 2018.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/eric-church-releases-huge-61-days-in-church-live-set-w501112 |title=Eric Church Releases Huge '61 Days in Church' Live Set |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=2017-09-05 |access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1786110/eric-church-unveils-61-days-in-church/ |title=Eric Church Unveils 61 Days in Church |publisher=CMT |date=2017-01-09 |access-date=2017-11-14}}{{dead link|date=July 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1786816/eric-churchs-new-61-days-in-church-release-covers-the-band-lynyrd-skynyrd-and-more/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170923005817/http://www.cmt.com/news/1786816/eric-churchs-new-61-days-in-church-release-covers-the-band-lynyrd-skynyrd-and-more/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 23, 2017 |title=Eric Church's New 61 Days in Church Release Covers The Band, Lynyrd Skynyrd and More |publisher=CMT |date=2017-09-22 |access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/eric-church-61-days-in-church-live-music/ |title=Eric Church Reveals '61 Days in Church' Live Collection |website=Theboot.com |date=September 2017 |access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref> The collection includes 124 tracks all of which were recorded live at the 61 shows of his 2017 Holdin' My Own Tour. The set includes two songs from each concert of the tour with the exception of the final two Nashville shows, which feature three songs from each night. He had already began releasing the album in stages for free on digital streaming services in September 2017. On July 12, 2018, Church announced via social media that he would release his sixth album, ''[[Desperate Man (album)|Desperate Man]]'', on October 5, 2018. He released the album's first single and [[Desperate Man (song)|title track]] the following day.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ericchurch/status/1017397920142897152|title=Eric Church on Twitter|publisher=[[Twitter]]|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref>

===2020–present: ''Heart & Soul''===
On November 11, 2020, Church won the Entertainer of the Year award at the [[54th Annual Country Music Association Awards]]. He performed "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]" alongside [[Jazmine Sullivan]] at [[Super Bowl LV]]. On April 16, 2021, Church released the album ''[[Heart & Soul (Eric Church album)|Heart]]'', followed by the album ''[[Heart & Soul (Eric Church album)|&]]'', on April 20, and ''[[Heart & Soul (Eric Church album)|Soul]]'', on April 23. The triple-album release contains 24 songs in total, including the singles Heart On Fire and "[[Hell of a View]]".<ref>{{Cite magazine|first=Joseph|last=Hudak|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/eric-church-new-album-heart-and-soul-1117530/|title=Eric Church Is Releasing Three New Albums|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=January 21, 2021|access-date=March 4, 2021}}</ref> In October 2021, after two of his bandmates tested positive for [[COVID-19]], Church performed two solo concerts on his The Gather Again Tour. The solo shows were in Pittsburgh on October 8 and Philadelphia on October 9.<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Nicholson|first=Jessica|title=Eric Church Sets 2 Solo Shows After Bandmates Test Positive for COVID-19|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/9643045/eric-church-band-covid-solo-concerts/|date=October 8, 2021|access-date=October 10, 2021|magazine=Billboard}}</ref> On February 22, 2022, Church was announced to perform at the 57th [[Academy of Country Music Awards]] on March 7, 2022.<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Grein|first=Paul|title=Carrie Underwood, Eric Church & More Added to 2022 ACM Awards' Performance Roster|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/awards/2022-acm-awards-performers-roster-additions-1235034492/|date=February 22, 2022|access-date=February 23, 2022|magazine=Billboard}}</ref>

==Personal life==
On January 8, 2008, Church married music publisher Katherine Blasingame at West Glow Resort in [[Blowing Rock, North Carolina]]. At the wedding, Church performed "You Make It Look So Easy", a song he wrote for Blasingame. On October 3, 2011, their first son, Boone McCoy Church, was born;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2011/10/06/eric-church-welcomes-son-boone-mccoy/ |title=Eric Church Welcomes Son Boone McCoy – Moms & Babies – Celebrity Babies and Kids – Moms & Babies – People.com |website=Celebritybabies.people.com |date=2012-03-22 |access-date=2014-02-11 |archive-date=2014-02-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222051309/http://celebritybabies.people.com/2011/10/06/eric-church-welcomes-son-boone-mccoy/ |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2011/03/24/eric-church-wife-baby/ |title=Eric Church Baby News Brings 'Two Pink Lines' Full Circle |website=Theboot.com |date=2011-04-19 |access-date=2014-02-11}}</ref> he is the subject of Church's song "Three Year Old". On February 15, 2015, their second son, Tennessee Hawkins "Hawk" Church was born.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etonline.com/music/159992_eric_church_welcomes_second_son_tennessee_hawkins |title=Eric Church Welcomes Second Son Tennessee Hawkins  |website=Etonline.com |date=2015-02-19 |access-date=2015-02-20}}</ref> Their home (along with Church's "[[man cave]]"), located in Nashville, was featured in an episode of [[Country Music Television|CMT]]'s ''Cribs''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1579702/eric-church-marries-in-north-carolina.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091223035514/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1579702/eric-church-marries-in-north-carolina.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 23, 2009|title=Eric Church Marries in North Carolina|date=January 15, 2008|access-date= February 27, 2010|publisher=CMT News}}</ref>

The Chief Cares Fund is a foundation organized by Eric and Katherine Church in 2013. The non-profit organization has been used to help underprivileged families in Tennessee, North Carolina, and even as far as helping orphans in Nepal receive clothing, proper bedding, and schooling. The foundation has also delivered Bibles to Haiti and helps fund Humane Society no-kill animal shelters. People can donate to the foundation on Eric Church's website by simply donating or by purchasing exclusive Chief Cares Platinum Tickets to his concerts where money from the tickets go to the Chief Cares Fund.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Chief Cares – Eric Church|url = http://ericchurch.com/chiefcares|website = Eric Church|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref>

In November 2022, North Carolina Governor [[Roy Cooper]] awarded Church the North Carolina Award, the state's highest civilian honor.<ref>{{Cite web |title=North Carolina Awards {{!}} NC DNCR |url=https://www.ncdcr.gov/about/special-programs/north-carolina-awards |access-date=2022-11-22 |website=Ncdcr.gov |language=en}}</ref>

Church wears his signature aviator sunglasses as a result of wearing contact lenses. When his career was getting started, he was forced to deal with the heat from the stage lights drying out his contacts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fwo51o6xsTA| archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211113/fwo51o6xsTA| archive-date=2021-11-13 | url-status=live|title=Eric Church talks sunglasses inside & Blake Shelton beef| website=[[YouTube]]}}{{cbignore}}</ref> As he began performing in larger venues, his aviators and [[Von Dutch]] denim trucker hat became his trademark.

Church has become an avid advocate for the use of [[cannabis]], reflected in songs such as "[[Smoke a Little Smoke]]"; at the time of that song's release, Church's record label urged him not to release the song, though it had minor success as a single.<ref>{{cite web|author=Eric Church / |url=http://ericchurch.com/forum/eric-church-blazes-his-own-path |title=Eric Church blazes his own path |access-date=2014-02-11 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105031439/http://ericchurch.com/forum/eric-church-blazes-his-own-path |archive-date=November 5, 2013 }}</ref> Church has also referenced marijuana use in other songs like "The Joint" and "I'm Gettin' Stoned", and has even been the subject of a marijuana joke at the 49th ACM Awards where [[Blake Shelton]] and [[Luke Bryan]] referred to Eric Church as the [[Willie Nelson]] for the new-country generation and compared Eric Church's dressing room to a cannabis dispensary.

Church opened Chief's, a bar, restaurant, and performance venue in downtown Nashville in April 2024.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/pamwindsor/2024/04/05/eric-church-on-chiefs-and-the-special-partnership-behind-his-new-nashville-bar--music-venue/|title=Eric Church & Developer Ben Weprin On The Partnership Behind ‘Chief’s’ - Nashville’s Newest Downtown Bar|first=Pam|last=Windsor|website=Forbes.com}}</ref>

==Musical styles==
Church's style has been described as [[country rock]], [[outlaw country]], and [[southern rock]]. Church's influences include [[Hank Williams Jr.]], [[Merle Haggard]], [[Little Feat]], [[The Band]], [[Kris Kristofferson]], [[The Grateful Dead]], [[Ray Wylie Hubbard]] and [[Waylon Jennings]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/|title=MSN &#124; Outlook, Office, Skype, Bing, Breaking News, and Latest Videos|website=Msn.com}}</ref> Church has also said that many [[hard rock]] and [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] bands influenced his music, including [[Metallica]] and [[AC/DC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dhNQj96pLMo | archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211113/dhNQj96pLMo| archive-date=2021-11-13 | url-status=live|title=Eric Church – Musical Influences |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=2012-01-30 |access-date=2014-02-11}}{{cbignore}}</ref>

'''Gary Ronnie Stewart''' (May 28, 1944 – December 16, 2003)<ref>Some sources state he was born in 1945, but Kentucky birth records and the [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] death index proves he was born in 1944. The latter confirms his death date. See Gary R Stewart birth record, Commonwealth of Kentucky, vol. 061, certificate number 30044, 1944.</ref> was an American musician and songwriter, known for his distinctive [[vibrato]] voice and his [[outlaw country]] sound influenced by [[southern rock]]. At the height of his popularity in the mid-1970s, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine described him as the "king of [[Honky tonk|honkytonk]]."<ref>{{cite magazine | last = DeVoss | first = David | title = A Honky-Tonk Man | magazine = Time | location=New York | date =  September 27, 1976 | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,918379,00.html?internalid=ACA | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071103145756/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,918379,00.html?internalid=ACA | url-status = dead | archive-date = November 3, 2007 | access-date = 2008-02-10}}  He was often introduced as the "King of Honky-Tonk"; see, for instance, the intro to his 2003 live album ''Live at Billy Bob's''.</ref> He had a series of country chart hits from the mid- to late 1970s, the biggest of which was "[[She's Actin' Single (I'm Drinkin' Doubles)]]", which topped the U.S. country singles chart in 1975.

On December 16, 2003, Stewart died of a [[suicide by gun|self-inflicted gunshot wound]], one month after the death of his wife.<ref name="auto"/><ref name="Flippo">{{cite news  | last = Flippo | first = Chet | title = Honky-Tonk Singer Gary Stewart Dies: Out of Hand country rocker apparently committed suicide | work = CMT.com | date = December 17, 2003 | url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1482923/20031217/stewart_gary_1_.jhtml | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070630105933/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1482923/20031217/stewart_gary_1_.jhtml | url-status = dead | archive-date = June 30, 2007 | access-date = 2008-02-10}}</ref><ref name="Passy">{{cite news  | last = Passy | first = Charles  | title = The Ballad of Gary & Mary Lou: Gary Stewart was a Hard-Partying Country Star, the King of Honky-Tonk, but it was his Devoted Lou Who Kept His Life Together, and When She Died, He Just Couldn't Go On | work = Palm Beach Post | date = March 14, 2004 | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-92192627.html | access-date = 2008-02-10}}{{dead link|date=February 2019|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>

== Career ==

Learning guitar and piano, Stewart began touring with local bands and writing songs in his teens.  He married Mary Lou Taylor, who was more than three years his senior, at age seventeen and began working days in an airplane factory.  He still played in rock and country bands at night.  While playing in an [[Okeechobee, Florida]], honky-tonk known as the Wagon Wheel, Stewart met country singer [[Mel Tillis]], who advised Stewart to travel to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] to pitch his songs.  He recorded a few songs for the small Cory label in 1964 and began co-writing songs with local policeman Bill Eldridge.  Stewart and Eldridge wrote [[Stonewall Jackson (musician)|Stonewall Jackson's]] 1965 country hit, "Poor Red Georgia Dirt". Signed to the [[Kapp Records|Kapp]] label in 1968, Stewart made several unsuccessful recordings but several songwriting successes followed, for artists like [[Billy Walker (musician)|Billy Walker]] ("She Goes Walking Through My Mind", "Traces of a Woman", "It's Time to Love Her"), [[Cal Smith]] ("You Can't Housebreak a Tomcat", "It Takes Me All Night Long"), and [[Nat Stuckey]] ("Sweet Thang And Cisco"). He even played piano for a time in [[Charley Pride]]'s band the Pridesmen, and can be heard on Pride's live ''In Person'' double-album. Disappointed with [[Music Row]], however, he soon returned to Florida and resumed playing countrified rock 'n' roll in local clubs and bars.<ref>''Country Music: The Rough Guide'', pp. 376–377; "A Honky-Tonk Man"; "Little Junior, King of the Honky-Tonks: The Life and Death of Gary Stewart"; ''Gary Stewart: Biography''; {{cite book | last = Stambler | first = Irwin | author2 = Grelun Landon | title = Country Music: The Encyclopedia | publisher = St. Martin's Press | year = 1997 | location = New York | pages = [https://archive.org/details/countrymusicency00stam/page/464 464–465] | url = https://archive.org/details/countrymusicency00stam/page/464 | isbn = 0-312-15121-7 | url-access = registration }}, {{cite book | last = Bogdanov | first = Vladimir |author2=Chris Woodstra |author3=Stephen Thomas Erlewine  | title = All Music Guide to Country: The Definitive Guide to Country Music | publisher = Backbeat Books | year = 2003 | location = San Francisco | pages = 721–722 | isbn = 0-87930-760-9}}</ref>  In 1970 [[Motown Records]], hoping to get Nashville artists to record their songs, paid Stewart $30 to record countrified demos of "[[Baby I Need Your Loving]]", "[[Yester-Me, Yester-You, Yesterday]]", and "[[I Can't Help Myself (Sugar Pie Honey Bunch)]]".<ref name="Betts">{{cite web |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/hear-tragic-country-singer-gary-stewarts-rare-motown-demo-for-record-store-day-629194/ |title=Hear Tragic Country Singer Gary Stewart's Rare Motown Demo for Record Store Day |last=Betts |first=Stephen L. |publisher=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=2018-04-20 |access-date=2020-07-31 }}</ref>

== Peak of career ==
{{quote box|quoted=1|quote=In case it's not clear why [[rock and roll]]ers are so excited about a new [[country music|country]] singer, it's because he really sings [[rockabilly]], which supposedly flourished for a few years in the mid-'50s and then vanished. What I like best about this compilation of flop singles from a few years ago is the way Stewart transforms rockabilly's adolescent phobias about wimmin into unabashed [[burlesque]]s involving the likes of 'Big Bertha' and 'The Snuff Queen.'|source=—Review of ''You're Not the Woman You Used to Be'' in ''[[Christgau's Record Guide: Rock Albums of the Seventies]]'' (1981)<ref name="CG">{{cite book|last=Christgau|first=Robert|author-link=Robert Christgau|year=1981|title=[[Christgau's Record Guide: Rock Albums of the Seventies]]|publisher=[[Ticknor & Fields]]|isbn=089919026X|chapter=Consumer Guide '70s: S|chapter-url=https://www.robertchristgau.com/get_chap.php?k=S&bk=70|access-date=March 12, 2019}}</ref>|width=25%|align=right|style=padding:8px;}}

Stewart was dropped from Kapp and then from [[Decca Records|Decca]], but a series of demo tapes, including the countrified Motown tunes, found their way into the hands of producer [[Roy Dea]], who convinced Jerry Bradley to sign Stewart to [[RCA Records]].  He returned to Nashville in 1973 and recorded a cover version of "[[Ramblin' Man (Allman Brothers Band song)|Ramblin' Man]]" by the [[The Allman Brothers Band|Allman Brothers]], both of whom were Stewart's personal friends. It charted at only #63 on the country chart, but his follow-up, 1974's "Drinkin' Thing" became a top ten hit. His album ''[[Out of Hand]]'' was released in early 1975. "Out of Hand", the title cut, became a #4 country hit and was followed by the #1 hit "She's Actin' Single (I'm Drinkin' Doubles)".<ref name="ReferenceA">''Country Music: The Rough Guide'', pp. 376–377; "A Honky-Tonk Man"; "Little Junior, King of the Honky-Tonks: The Life and Death of Gary Stewart"; ''Gary Stewart: Biography''; ''Country Music: The Encyclopedia'', pp. 464–465; ''All Music Guide to Country: The Definitive Guide to Country Music'', pp. 721–722.</ref><ref name="Betts"/>

The album ''Out of Hand'', which climbed to #6 on the Billboard country album chart, has since become one of the most critically lauded country albums of the 1970s. ''[[Village Voice]]'' critic [[Robert Christgau]] gave the album an A− saying that it "was the best regular issue country LP I've heard in about five years."<ref>{{cite book | last = Christgau | first = Robert | title = Rock Albums of the '70s: A Critical Guide | publisher = Da Capo Press | year = 1990 | location = New York | pages = 373 | isbn = 0-306-80409-3}}</ref> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' gave it high praise as well, stating that, "With practitioners like Stewart around, honky-tonk—and rockabilly—may not be dead yet."<ref>{{cite magazine | last = Miller | first = Jim | title = Gary Stewart: Out of Hand | magazine = Rolling Stone | issue = 190 | date = July 3, 1975 | url = https://www.rollingstone.com/artists/garystewart/albums/album/281494/review/5943163/out_of_hand | access-date = 2008-02-10}}{{dead link|date=August 2021|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Thom Jurek of [[AllMusic]] later gave the album five of five stars and stated that a "strong case could be made for ''Out of Hand'' as one of the Top 100 country records of all time. It might be in this writer's Top Ten!"<ref>''All Music Guide to Country: The Definitive Guide to Country Music'', pp. 721–722.</ref> Country music critic [[Bill C. Malone|Bill Malone]] called ''Out of Hand'' "one of the greatest honky-tonk country albums ever recorded."<ref>{{cite book | year =  2001 | title = Don't Get Above Your Raisin': Country Music and the Southern Working Class | url =  https://archive.org/details/dontgetaboveyourr00malo | url-access =  registration | author = Bill C. Malone | pages=[https://archive.org/details/dontgetaboveyourr00malo/page/151 151-152] | author-link = Bill C. Malone  | publisher = [[University of Illinois Press]] | isbn = 0-252-02678-0}}</ref>

Later in 1975, [[MCA Records|MCA]] released Stewart's old Kapp material scoring a #15 hit with the single "You're Not the Woman You Use to Be".  For the rest of the 1970s Stewart played the honky tonks with his road band, The Honky Tonk Liberation Army, and recorded similar albums with modest success for RCA: 1976's ''Steppin' Out''; 1977's ''Your Place or Mine'' (which featured guest artists [[Nicolette Larson]], [[Emmylou Harris]], and [[Rodney Crowell]]); and 1978's ''[[Little Junior (album)|Little Junior]]''. These albums spawned several hit singles, including: "Flat Natural Born Good-Timin' Man", "In Some Room Above the Street", "Single Again", "Your Place or Mine", "Quits", and "Whiskey Trip".<ref>''Country Music: The Rough Guide'', pp. 376–377; "A Honky-Tonk Man"; "Little Junior, King of the Honky-Tonks: The Life and Death of Gary Stewart"; ''Gary Stewart: Biography''; ''Country Music: The Encyclopedia'', pp. 464–465; ''All Music Guide to Country: The Definitive Guide to Country Music'', pp. 721–722; ''Rock Albums of the '70s: A Critical Guide'', p. 373.</ref> His 1977 ode to marital distress entitled "Ten Years of This", from the album ''Your Place or Mine'', was a favorite of [[Bob Dylan]] and a #16 hit.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|last1=McDonough|first1=Jimmy|title=LITTLE JUNIOR, KING OF THE HONKY-TONKS The life and death of Gary Stewart|url=http://www.furious.com/perfect/garystewart.html|website=Perfect Sound Forever|access-date=8 September 2015}}</ref> Dylan noted his admiration of Stewart in a 1978 interview with ''[[Playboy]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.interferenza.net/bcs/interw/play78.htm|title=PLAYBOY INTERVIEW: BOB DYLAN|website=Interferenza.net|access-date=April 25, 2019}}</ref>

==Later career==
Though his late 1970s albums were well received by critics and his core fans, Stewart never established a large rapport with the general music audience. He was often labeled as "too country" for rock listeners and "too rock" for country fans. In 1980, he released the [[Chips Moman]]-produced ''[[Cactus and a Rose]]'' which featured Southern rockers [[Gregg Allman]], [[Dickey Betts]], [[Mike Lawler]], and [[Bonnie Bramlett]]. It did not garner much airplay and RCA teamed Stewart up with songwriter [[Dean Dillon]] for a pair of duet records. Soon after, Stewart returned to Florida, where alcoholism and drug use kept him from recording for much of the 1980s. His son, Gary Joseph Stewart, committed suicide late in the decade as well. Stewart signed with the [[HighTone Records|HighTone]] label in 1988 and recorded three albums over the next five years. These albums included fan favorites like the minor hit "An Empty Glass (That's the Way the Day Ends)" (written by Stewart and Dillon), "Let's Go Jukin'" (written by Stewart and Betts), and "Brand New Whiskey" (written by Stewart and his wife).<ref name="ReferenceA"/>

Stewart continued to tour through the 1990s, playing venues such as [[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth's]] [[Billy Bob's Texas]] several times a year.<ref>{{cite web | title = Gary Stewart | work = Lone Star Music | url = http://www.lonestarmusic.com/index.php?file=a-artist&iArtistId=975 | access-date = 2008-02-13}}</ref> During this time, Bob Dylan, while touring with [[Tom Petty]] in Florida, drove out of his way to meet Stewart, "confessing that he'd played Stewart's ode to marital malaise 'Ten Years of This' over and over, the record casting a spell over him."<ref name="auto"/> In 2003, Stewart released ''Live at Billy Bob's Texas'', his first album in ten years and his first-ever live album. Reviewers at Allmusic gave it good marks.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/live-at-billy-bobs-texas-mw0000019113|title=Live at Billy Bob's Texas - Gary Stewart - Songs, Reviews, Credits|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=April 25, 2019}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Stewart was born in [[Jenkins, Kentucky]], on May 28, 1944, the son of George and Georgia Stewart. He was named after the actor [[Gary Cooper]].  In 1959 his father, a [[coal mining|coal miner]], sustained an injury while working in the mines, and shortly afterwards the family moved to [[Fort Pierce, Florida|Fort Pierce]], a city on [[Florida]]'s [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] coast.<ref>"A Honky-Tonk Man"; {{cite book | last = Wolff | first = Kurt |author2=Orla Duane  | title = Country Music: The Rough Guide | publisher = Rough Guides | year = 2000 | location = London | pages = 376–377 | isbn = 1-85828-534-8}}, {{cite web | last = McDonough | first = Jimmy | title = Little Junior, King of the Honky-Tonks: The Life and Death of Gary Stewart | work = Perfect Sound Forever | year = 2004 | url = http://www.furious.com/perfect/garystewart.html | format = Electronic Journal | access-date = 2008-02-10}}, and {{cite web | title = Gary Stewart: Biography | work = CMT.com | url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/stewart_gary_1_/bio.jhtml | access-date = 2008-02-10}}</ref>

On November 26, 2003, the day before [[Thanksgiving]], his wife of nearly 43 years, Mary Lou, died of [[pneumonia]]. Stewart, who had been scheduled to play Billy Bob's three days later, canceled his concert appearances. His friends later told reporters that he was extremely despondent after Mary Lou's death. 

On December 16, his daughter's boyfriend and Stewart's very close friend, Bill Hardman, visited his Fort Pierce, Florida, home to check on his welfare. They found Stewart dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the neck.<ref name="auto"/><ref name="Flippo"/><ref name="Passy"/>

==Posthumous releases==
In 2005, the Australia-based [[Raven Records]] released a CD containing Stewart's second and fourth albums: ''Steppin' Out'' and ''Little Junior'', augmented with three previously unreleased bonus tracks from the RCA vaults. It was followed by a second Raven release containing ''Brotherly Love'' and ''Those Were the Days'', expanded and augmented by rare bonus tracks which were previously unavailable on CD.<ref name=Discogs_GaryStewart>{{cite web| title=Gary Stewart| publisher=[[Discogs]]| url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/264158-Gary-Stewart| access-date=2020-07-01}}</ref> Two songs from the era featured on this collection later became hits when recorded by [[George Strait]].{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}

[[Wounded Bird Records]] released a CD in 2010 which included the albums ''Cactus and a Rose'' and ''Collector's Series'', a comprehensive greatest hits collection.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}  In 2010, UK-based Floating World Records reissued Stewart's albums from the late 1980s and early 1990s: ''Brand New'', ''Battleground'' and ''I'm a Texan''. Floating World purchased the entire back catalog from the now-defunct [[HighTone Records|HighTone]] label.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}  In 2013, UK-based Morello Records released a CD containing Stewart's first and third albums: ''Out of Hand'' and ''Your Place or Mine''.  In 2017, Morello released a CD containing Stewart's fifth and sixth albums: ''Gary'' and ''Cactus and a Rose''.<ref name=Discogs_GaryStewart/>

For [[Record Store Day]] in 2018, the Delmore Recording Society label released a 45 rpm single called ''Mowtown'' containing Stewart's versions of the [[Motown]] classics "[[Baby I Need Your Loving]]" and "[[Yester-Me, Yester-You, Yesterday]]".  Stewart recorded the tracks (and the unreleased "[[I Can't Help Myself (Sugar Pie Honey Bunch)]]") in 1970 when Motown Records wanted demos of their songs in a Nashville style, hoping to interest [[country music]] artists in recording Motown songs.  Stewart was paid $30 for the session.<ref name="Betts"/>

In May 2020, the [[Austin, TX|Austin]]-based band [[Mike and the Moonpies]] released ''Touch of You: The Lost Songs of Gary Stewart'', an album of unreleased songs written or co-written by Stewart.  The band's version of Stewart's "Smooth Shot of Whiskey", featuring [[Mark Wystrach]] of the band [[Midland (band)|Midland]] was released as a single.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Freeman |first=Jon |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/mike-and-the-moonpies-gary-stewart-album-1005204/ |title=Mike and the Moonpies Cover Gary Stewart on New Album, 'Touch of You' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=2020-05-26 |access-date=2020-06-30 }}</ref>
